title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: Miles got a saxophone for his birthday.

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: Miles practiced, and practiced, until his mama and papa couldn't stand it anymore, and his mama said:

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: And so he did, as loud as could be.

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: Miles strolled down Main Street, where he met a drummer named Al;

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: up Swamp Lane, where he met a guitarist named Bert;

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: and over Bayou Bridge, where he met a trumpet player named Doc.

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: 'Hey, let's play some music!' said Miles.

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: And they played as loud as they could.

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: Soon the whole town cried out: [[Swamp bands play in the swamp!!]]

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: But down in the swamp at the edge of town the sharp-toothed, long-tailed, yellow-eyed alligators said:

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: [[Come and play for the Alligator Ball!]]

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: [[Saturday night, after the sun goes down!]]

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: Saturday night when the sun went down, the alligators came from miles around. They were dressed in their finest.

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: The Swamp Band played their favorite song.

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: [[Mama don't allow no music playin' round here! Mama don't allow no music playin' round here!]]

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: [[Now, we don't care what Mama don't allow, we're gonna play that music anyhow!!]]

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: The Swamp Band played far into the night.

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: When the music was over the band was hungry. So were the alligators.

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: The alligators snapped their jaws and smacked their lips.

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: [[Wait! How about one more song before dinner?]]

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: [[When the moon is rising, and the moss hangs low; when the swamp is quiet, and the waters move slow; that's the time to sing softly, and lay your head awfully far down in the gooey, damp mud.]]

title: MAMA DON'T ALLOW
author: THACHER HURD
text: The alligators fell fast asleep. Miles piloted the riverboat back to Swampville. The Swamp Band tiptoed home, playing that lullaby as quiet as could be.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: and the boy loved stars very much.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: and wished he had one of his very own.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: He dreamed of how this star

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: The boy decided he would try to catch one.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: He thought that getting up early

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: in the morning would be best,

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: because then the star would be tired

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: from being up in the sky all night.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: The next day he set out at sunrise.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: But he could not see a star anywhere.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: So he sat down and waited for one to appear.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: to go away, he saw a star.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: to jump up and grab it.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: But the star was still way out of reach.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: But it was much too heavy

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: If only he could fly up in a spaceship and

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: just grab the star. But the only

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: spaceship he owned was made of paper,

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: and it didn't fly well at all.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: Perhaps he could get a seagull to help

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: him fly up into the sky to reach his star?

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: But the only seagull he could find

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: Just hen he noticed something floating in the water.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: It was the prettiest star he had ever seen!

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: Just a baby star. It must have fallen from the sky.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: He tried to fish it out with his hands.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: But when the boy reached out to touch the

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: star, it just rippled through his fingers.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: Now the boy was sad. But in his heart,

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: the wish just wouldn't give up.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: And that's when he saw it

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: washed up on the bright golden sand.

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: The boy had caught a star!

title: HOW TO CATCH A STAR
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: A star of his very own.

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: and one day he found a penguin at his door.

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: The boy didn't know where it had come from

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: but it began to follow him everywhere.

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: the boy thought it must lost.

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: So the boy decided to help the penguin

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: He checked in the Lost and Found Office.

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: But no one was missing a penguin.

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: He asked some birds if they knew

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: That night, the boy couldn't sleep for

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: disappointment. He wanted to help the

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: penguin but he didn't know how.

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: The next morning he discovered that

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: penguins come from the South Pole.

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: But how could he get there?

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: He ran down to the harbor and asked a

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: big ship to take them to the South Pole.

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: But his voice was much too small to

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: be heard over the ship's horn.

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: So together, he and the penguin would row

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: to the South Pole. The boy took his rowboat

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: out of the cupboard and they tested it for

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: They packed everything they would need...

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: They rowed south for many days...

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: and nights with the boy telling stories all

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: the way. The penguin listened to everything

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: They floated through good weather and bad,

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: when the waves were as big as mountains...

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: until they came to the South Pole.

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: Suddenly it looked sad again as

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: the boy helped it out of the boat.

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: and floated away. But as he looked back,

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: the penguin looked sadder than ever.

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: It felt strange to be on his own...

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: The penguin wasn't lost. He was just lonely.

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: Quickly he turned the boat around

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: and headed back to the South Pole

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: Sadly the boy set off for home.

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: There was no point telling stories

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: because there was no one to listen,

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: except the wind and the waves.

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: but then the boy saw something

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: in the water ahead of him.

title: LOST AND FOUND
author: OLIVER JEFFERS
text: And so the boy and his friend went

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: His life was a book of his own writing, one orderly page

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: after another. He would open it every morning and write

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: of his joys and sorrows, of all that he knew

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: and everything that he hoped for.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: But every story had its upset.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: till everything Morris knew was scattered 

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: even the words of his book

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: He didn't know what to do or which

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: way to go. So he began to wander,

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: Then a happy bit of happenstance came his way.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: Rather then looking down, as had become his habit.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: Morris Lessmore looked up. Drifting though the sky

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: above him. Morris saw a lovely lady. She was being pulled

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: along by a festive squadron of flying books.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: Morris wondered if his books could fly.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: It would only fall to the ground with a depressing thud.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: The flying lady knew Morris simply needed a good story.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: So she sent him her favorite. The book was an amiable fellow,

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: And urged Morris to follow him.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: The book led him to an extraordinary building

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: Morris slowly walked inside and discovered

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: the most mysterious and inviting room he had ever seen.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: It was filled with the fluttering of countless pages,

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: and Morris could hear the fair chatter of a thousand

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: different stories, as if each book was whispering

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: Then his new friend flew up to him and landed on his

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: arm. It held itself open, as if hoping to be read.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: Morris tried to keep the books in some sort of

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: order, but they always mixed themselves up.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: The tragedies needed cheering up and would visit

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: with the comedians. The encyclopedias, weary of facts,

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: would relax with the comic books and fictions.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: All in all it was an agreeable jumble.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: Morris found great satisfaction in caring for the books,

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: gently fixing them with fragile bindings,

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: and unfolding the dog-eared ages of others.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: Morris liked to share the books with others.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: Sometimes it was a favorite that everyone loved,

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: and other times he found a lonely little volume

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: At night, after all the stories that needed telling had been told

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: and everyone had settled down to their proper places on the

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: shelves, the great big dictionary would get in the last word:

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: It was then that Morris Lessmore would once again

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: write in his own book. He wrote of his joys and sorrows

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: of all that he knew and everything that he hoped for.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: Now his old friends took care of him

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: the way he had once cared for them

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: and they read themselves to him

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: the last page in his book.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: The books were sorry, but they understood.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: Morris put on his hat and took his cane.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: As he went to the door, he turned and smiled and then

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: waved goodbye. 'I'll carry you all in here

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: he said,  and pointed to his heart.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: I'll carry you all in here.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: The book waved their pages, and Morris Lessmore flew away.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: And as he flew, he changed back to the way he'd been

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: that long ago day when they'd all first met.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: The books were quiet for a while. Then they noticed

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: that Morris Lessmore had left something behind.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: 'It's his book,' said his oldest friend. Inside was Morris's story.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: All of his joys and sorrows,

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: and everything that he hoped for.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: Then the books heard a small, expectant sound. There in

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: the doorway was a little girl. She looked around with wonder.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: Morris Lessmore's book flew up to her and opened it's pages.

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: And so our story ends as it began...

title: THE FANTASTIC FLYING BOOKS OF MR. MORRIS LESSMORE
author: WILLIAM JOYCE
text: .. with the opening of a book.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: My little brother Alexander whispered that to me while we were watching a funny opera called The Mikado.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: "To that place where they are singing. Pajan."

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: "Yes, that's where I want to go. Now. Please."

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: I had a piano lesson the next day with the dreaded Mrs. Kackleman, so it seemed like a great idea.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: I called the travel agent, Mr. Google.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: "Hello, Mr. Google. Two seats on the Japan plane please. Thank you Mr. Google."

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: We kissed our parents good-bye. They said come back soon. Bring back presents.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: And off we went. Into the blue sky. To Japan.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: Which as I explained to the miniature midget (as I sometimes call my brother) is a skinny island next to China and the people are Japanese.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: "Knees? They walk on their knees?" he screeched.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: "No," I screamed. "They are of Japan, Japanese."

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: "Oh, I knew that," he said quietly.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: We landed in a city called Tokyo. The people are very polite and are always saying, "Domo arigato gozaimasu," which means, "Thank you very very much."

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: The alphabet looks like little stick pictures. We looked at a sign.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: TWO HEADS ARE BETTER THAN ONE

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: We hopped into a red taxi with a driver in white gloves and sharp black hair. Everyone in Japan has black hair. Not red, not yellow, not green, just black.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: Narrow streets whizzed by. Little houses and stores. People on bicycles, people walking.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: Our hotel was a ryokan, which is like a Japanese home. You take your shoes off before you step inside, so you must make sure that your socks don't have holes. You walk on mats called tatami. And you sleep on the floor on a cushy pad called a futon and cover yourself with a quilt as soft as a cloud. We sat on the floor at a table and had jasmine tea and rice crackers.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: Outside our window we heard music. Under fluttering cherry blossoms women danced to the playing of flutes.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: The door knocked. In walked our guide, Hiroko. She was going to show us many places.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: Alexander made up a poem that I was very proud of.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: Hey Hiroko, are you loco? Would you like a cup of cocoa?

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: We opened the present that Hiroko brought - a book with pictures of schoolchildren many years ago. They were dressed in beautiful robes called kimonos. Now children wear school uniforms and the girls have braids that point to the ground. We wanted to meet the children at school. We jumped up.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: "I will take you," said Hiroko. We went to the subway.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: The subway was shining and quiet. The workers stood in crisp uniforms. The train smoothed into the station and was full of people. We were like marshmallows all stuffed together in a bag bouncing along, but nobody stuck their elbow in my ear.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: In the school, the children bowed hello, singing a good morning song. Other children were reading a story about a man who traveled to a magic castle under the sea on the back of a turtle. Other children were learning music and the birds chirped on trees.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: Walking in the sun, we passed a man sitting on a bench. His black, crooked cane poked the ground and looked like a snake.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: We went to a noodle restaurant. Alexander said they served oodles and poodles of noodles. The waiter brought us little hot wet white towels. We wiped our hands. The bowls of noodles arrived with chopsticks. Alexander's chopsticks kept flipping and flying through the air. I taught him how to use them and we all slurped our noodles, which is a perfectly fine thing to do in Japan.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: Strolling along, we came to a rock garden. There were big rocks that were like islands. All around them, sand was raked into patterns like the ocean. And even if one tiny leaf fell on the sand, a gardener would come and pluck it away using a long pole with a pin on the end. In the pond, big spotted carp wiggled to our feet. The quiet was so quiet that the quiet filled the air.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: Suddenly, a frog spoke to us. "Excuse me, would you like to hear my haiku?"

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: if he is a prince which I

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: We went to eat. At the restaurant we took off our shoes. Alexander was sure they were cooking our shoes.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: But really it was rice and vegetables tied with tiny seaweed bows.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: It was a dreamy night. We wandered through the city and went to a movie called Godzilla. This giant lizard clomped around Tokyo scaring everyone and Alexander said, "That Godzilla is my friend."

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: The next morning Hiroko came to our door.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: "This is a fishy morning," she announced. "I would like to take you to the fish market."

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: There are little places to eat raw fish called sushi, which frog boy (as I sometimes call my slippery brother) calls squishy.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: We walked to an old temple where people tied zillions of little pieces of paper with wishes on them to a tree. People pulled long heavy ropes that made big bells ring. And the sound of the ringing would ring up to the sky. Alexander wished for a flying bike and I wished for a dancing dog.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: "And now," said Hiroko, "we will take a bath."

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: She pointed to a mountain. We got on a little wooden train.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: In the middle of a pine forest was the bath. Alexander wanted to jump right in, but there are things you must do first. Like take off all your clothes. We sat on benches, scrubbed like crazy and rinsed with buckets of water. Then we scrubbed some more and rinsed some more. Then we stepped into the steamy water, sat down, closed our eyes and the smell of pines filled our noses and made us smile.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: Extremely clean, we went to a fancy cafÃ©. Alexander wrote poems. I blinked at the chandeliers. Our waiter curved over us with small sweet mountains of green ice.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: Hiroko said, "I want to take you to a play called Noh."

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: There were dragons and people in masks and nobody moved for one hour including Alexander who fell asleep.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: The next morning the door knocked and in walked Hiroko. She said, "Today I would like to take you on a very fast train. So fast it is called the Bullet Train." The train was so fast we were back before we left. That's fast.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: Hiroko's best friend, a beautiful movie star named Fujiko gave us a good-bye party. Paper lanterns swung in the breeze. The evening was warm. Alexander, my little brother spoke his farewell poem.

title: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN
author: MAIRA KALMAN
text: Full of presents we flew, into the arms of our parents. We were back. Back to the twins SalomÃ© and Mona. Back to the little green man who floats on the ceiling, and back to our good friend Bruno and his invisible paintings. But that is another story.

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: Oh, how Peter wished he could whistle!

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: He saw a boy playing with his dog. Whenever

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: the boy whistled, the dog ran straight to him.

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: Peter tried and tried to whistle, but he

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: couldn't. So instead he began to turn

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: Peter saw his dog, Willie, coming.

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: Quick as a wink, he hid in an empty

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: 'Wouldn't it be funny if I whistled?' Peter

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: thought. 'Willie would stop and look all

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: around to see who it was.'

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: Peter tried again to whistle---but still he

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: couldn't. So Willie just walked on.

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: Peter got out of the carton and started home.

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: On the way he took some colored chalks out

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: of his pocket and drew a long, long line.

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: He stood there and tried to whistle

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: again. He blew till his cheeks were

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: He went into his house and put on his

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: father's old hat to make himself feel more

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: grown-up. He looked into the mirror to

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: When his mother saw what he was doing,

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: Peter pretended that he was his father.

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: He said, 'I've come home early today, dear.

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: His mother answered, 'Why no, he's outside

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: 'Well, I'll go out and look for them,' said Peter.

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: First he walked a long a crack in the

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: sidewalk. Then he tried to run away

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: Suddenly ---- out came a real whistle!

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: Willie stopped and looked around to

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: 'It's me,' Peter shouted, and stood up.

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: Peter ran home to show his father and

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: They loved Peter's whistling. So did Wille.

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: Peter's mother asked him and Willie

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: to go on an errand to the grocery store.

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: He whistle all the way there,

title: WHISTLE FOR WILLIE
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: and he whistle all the way home.

title: I WANT MY HAT BACK

text: No. I haven't seen your hat.

title: I WANT MY HAT BACK

text: I would not eat a rabbit.

title: I WANT MY HAT BACK
author: JON KLASSEN
text: Don't ask me any more questions.

title: P IS FOR POTTY!
author: NAOMI KLEINBERG
text: Today Elmo and his mommy are babysitting for

title: P IS FOR POTTY!
author: NAOMI KLEINBERG
text: Elmo's little cousins, Albie and Baby Jo-Jo.

title: P IS FOR POTTY!

text: Elmo and Albie are busy playing. Jo-Jo is fussing.

title: P IS FOR POTTY!

text: 'It might be time for a diaper change, little Jo-Jo,'

title: P IS FOR POTTY!

text: I used to wear diapers like Jo-Jo,' Albie

title: P IS FOR POTTY!

title: P IS FOR POTTY!

title: P IS FOR POTTY!

title: P IS FOR POTTY!

title: P IS FOR POTTY!
author: NAOMI KLEINBERG

text: 'Cousin Elmo helped me learn how to use the

title: P IS FOR POTTY!

title: P IS FOR POTTY!

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: One day, a lion came into the library.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: He walked right past the circulation desk

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Mr. McBee ran down the hall to the head

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: 'But there's a lion!' said Mr. McBee.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: 'Is he breaking any rules?' asked Miss

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The lion wandered all around the library. He sniffed

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: He rubbed his head against the new book collection

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Then he padded over to the story corner and went

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: No one was sure what to do. There weren't any rules

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Soon it was time for story hour. There weren't any

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: rules about lions at story hour, either.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The story lady seemed a little nervous. But she read

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: out the first book's title in a good, clear voice. The lion

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: looked up. The story lady kept reading.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The lion stayed for the next story. And the story after

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: that. He waited for another story, but the children

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: 'Story hour is over,' a little girl told him. 'It's time

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The lion looked at the children. He looked at the

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: story lady. He looked at the closed books. Then he

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Miss Merriweather came striding out of

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: her office. 'Who is making that noise?'

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Miss Werriweather marched over to the lion.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: 'If you cannot be quiet, you will have

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: to leave,' she said in a stern voice. 'Those

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The lion kept roaring. He sounded sad.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The little girl tugged on Miss Merriweather's

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: dress. 'If he promises to be quiet, can he come

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: back for story hour tomorrow?' she asked.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The lion stopped roaring. He looked at

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Miss Merriweather looked back. Then she

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: said, 'Yes. A nice, quiet lion would certainly

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: be allowed to come back for story hour tomorrow.'

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The next day, the lion came back.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: 'Story hour is not until three o-clock.'

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The next day, the lion came early again. This time,

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Miss Merriweather asked him to lick all the envelopes

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Soon the lion began doing things without

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: being asked. He dusted the encyclopedias.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: He licked the envelopes. He let small children

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: stand on his back to reach books on the highest shelves.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Then he curled up in the story corner to

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: wait for story hour to begin.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: At first, the people in the library were

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: nervous about the lion. But soon they got

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: used to having him around. In fact, he

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: seemed very well suited for the library.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: His big feel were quiet on the library floor.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: He made a comfy backrest for the children

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: at story hour. And he never roared in the

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: They patted his soft head as he walked by.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: 'How did we ever get along without him?'

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Mr. McBee scowled when he heard that.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: They had always gotten along fine before.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: No lions were needed! Lions, he thought,

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: could not understand rules. They did not

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: One day, after he had dusted all the

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: envelopes and helped all the small children,

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: the lion padded down the hall to Miss

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Merriweather's office to see what else there

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: was to do. There was still some time left

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: 'I know something you can do. You can

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: bring a book back into the stacks for me.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Let me just get down from the shelf.'

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Miss Merriweather stepped up onto the

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: step stool. The book was just out of reach.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Miss Merriweather stood on her toes.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: 'Mr. McBee!' she called after a minute.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: But Mr. McBee was at the circulation

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: desk. He could not hear her calling.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The lion ran down the hall.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The lion put his big front paws up on the big

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: circulation desk and looked at Mr. McBee.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The lion whined. He pointed his nose down

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: the hall toward Miss. Merriweather's office.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Finally, the lion did the only thing he

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: could think of to do. He looked Mr. McBee

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: right in the eye. Then he opened his mouth

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: very wide. And he roared the loudest roar

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: he had ever roared in his life.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: 'You're not being quiet!' he said to

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Mr. McBee walked down the hall as

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The lion did not follow him. He had

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: broken the rules. He knew what that

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: meant. He hung his head and walked

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Merriweather!' he called as he walked.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: the rules! The lion broke the rules!'

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: He burst into Miss Merriweather's office.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: She was not in her chair.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: the floor behind her desk, 'there is

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: a good reason to break the rules. Even in

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: the library. Now please go call a doctor.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: I think I've broken my arm.'

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Mr. McBee ran to call a doctor.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The next day, things were back to normal.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Miss Merriweather's left arm was in a

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: cast. The doctor had told her not to work

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: 'I will have my lion to help me,' Miss

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Merriweather thought. But the lion did not

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: come to the library that morning.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Walked over to the story corner. The story

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Lady was just beginning a story for the

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: children. The lion was not there.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: People in the library kept looking up

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: from their books and computer screens,

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: hoping they would see a familiar furry

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: face. But the lion did not come that day.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The lion did not come the next day,

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: either. Or the next day after that.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: One evening, Mr. McBee stopped by

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Miss Merriweather's office on his way

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: out. 'Can I do anything for you before I go,

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: She was looking out the window. Her voice

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: was very quiet. Even for the library.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Mr. McBee frowned as he walked away.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: He thought there probably was something

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: he could do for Miss Merriweather, after all.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Mr. McBee left the library. But he did not go home.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: He looked under cars. He looked behind bushes.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: He looked in backyards and trash cans and tree houses.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Finally he circled all the way back to

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The lion was sitting outside, looking in

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The lion did not turn around.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: 'I thought you might like to know,'

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: said Mr. McBee, 'that there's a new rule

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: at the library. No roaring allowed, unless

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: you have a very good reason-say, if

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: you're trying to help a friend who's been

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The lion's ears twitched. He turned around.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: But Mr. McBee was already walking away.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: The next day, Mr. McBee walked down

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: the hall to Miss Merriweather's office.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: 'What is it, Mr. McBee?' asked Miss

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Merriweather in her new, sad, quiet voice.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: 'I thought you might like to know,' said

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Mr. McBee, 'that there's a lion. In the

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Miss Merriweather jumped up from her

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: chair and ran down the hall.

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: Mr. McBee smiled, 'No running!' he called

title: LIBRARY LION
author: MICHELLE KNUDSEN
text: a good reason to break the rules.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Once upon a time in Paris there

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: lived a little boy whose name

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: was Pascal. He had no brothers

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: or sisters, and he was very sad

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Once he brought home a lost

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: cat, and some time later a stray

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: house, and so Pascal was soon

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Then one day, on his way to

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: school, he caught sight of a fine

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: red balloon, tied to a street lamp.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Pascal laid his school bag on

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: the ground. He climbed up the

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: and ran off with it to the bus stop.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: But the conductor knew the rules. "No dogs," he said. "No large packages,

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: People with balloons leave them behind.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Pascal did not want to leave his balloon behind, so the conductor rang the

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: signal bell and the bus went on without him.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Pascal's school was a long way off, and when he finally reached the school

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: door it was already shut. To be late for school and with a balloon - that was

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: unheard of! Pascal was very worried.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Then he had an idea. He left his balloon with the janitor, who was sweeping

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: the yard. And since it was the first time that he had ever been late, he was

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: When school was over, the janitor, who had kept the balloon in his room for

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Pascal, gave it back to him.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: But it had begun to rain. And Pascal had to walk home because of those silly

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: rules about balloons on buses. But he thought his balloon shouldn't get wet.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: There was an old gentleman just going by, and Pascal asked him whether he

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: and the balloon could take shelter under his umbrella. So, from one umbrella

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: to another, Pascal made his way home.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: His mother was glad to see him finally come home. But since she had been

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: very worried, she was angry when she found out that it was a balloon that had

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: made Pascal late. She took the balloon, opened the window, and threw it out.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Now, usually when you let a balloon go, it flies away. But Pascal's balloon

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: stayed outside the window, and the two of them looked at each other through

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: the glass. Pascal was surprised that his balloon hadn't flown away, but not

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: really as surprised as all that. Friends will do all kinds of things for you. If the

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: friend happens to be a balloon, it doesn't fly away. So Pascal opened his

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: window quietly, took his balloon back inside, and hid it in his room.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: The next day, before he left for school, Pascal opened the window to let his

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: balloon out and told it to come to him when he called.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Then he picked up his school bag, kissed his mother good-by, and went

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: When he reached the street he called: "Balloon! Balloon!" and the balloon

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Then it began to follow Pascal - without being led by a string, just as if it were a dog following its master.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: But, like a dog, it didn't always

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: do as it was told. When Pascal

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Tried to catch it to cross the

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: didn't care. He walked up the

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: street just as if the balloon

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: weren't there at all and hid be-

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: hind the corner of a house. The

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: When they got to the bus stop,

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: balloon, you follow me. Don't lose

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: That was how the strangest sight

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: came to be seen in a Paris street-

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: When they reached Pascal's school, the balloon again tried not to let itself be

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: caught. But the bell was already ringing and the door was just about to close,

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: so Pascal had to hurry in alone. He was very worried.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: But the balloon flew over the school wall and got in line behind the children.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: The teacher was very surprised to see this strange new pupil, and when the

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: balloon tried to follow them into the classroom, the children made so much

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: noise that the principal came along to see what was happening.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: The principal tried to catch the balloon to put it out the door. But he couldn't.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: So he took Pascal by the hand and marched him out of school. The balloon left

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: The principal had urgent business at the Town Hall, and he didn't know what to

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: do with Pascal and his balloon. So he locked the boy up inside his office. The

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: balloon, he said to himself, would stay outside the door.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: But that wasn't the balloon's idea at all. When it saw that the principal had put

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: the key in his pocket, it sailed along behind him as he walked down the street.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: All the people knew the principal very well, and when they saw him walking

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: past followed by a balloon they shook their heads and said: "The principal's

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: playing a joke. It isn't right; a principal should be dignified, he shouldn't be

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: playing like one of the boys in his school."

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: The poor man tried very hard to catch the balloon, but he couldn't, so there was

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: nothing for him to do but put up with it. Outside the Town Hall the balloon

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: stopped. It waited for him in the street, and when the principal went back to

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: school the balloon was still behind him.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: The principal was only too glad to let Pascal out of his office, and to be rid of

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: On the way home Pascal stopped to look at a picture in a sidewalk exhibit. It

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: showed a little girl with a hoop. Pascal thought how nice it would be to have a

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: But just at that moment he met a real little girl, looking just like the one in the

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: picture. She was wearing a pretty white dress, and she held in her hand the

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Pascal wanted to be sure she noticed that his balloon was a magic one. But

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: his balloon wouldn't be caught, and the little girl began to laugh.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Pascal was angry. "What's the use of having a trained balloon if it won't do

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: what you want?" He said to himself. At that very moment some of the tough

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: boys of the neighborhood came by. They tried to catch the balloon as it trailed

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Along behind Pascal. But the balloon saw the danger. It flew to Pascal at once.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: He caught it and began to run, but more boys came to corner him from the

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: So Pascal let go of his balloon, which immediately rose high into the sky.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: While the boys were all looking up, Pascal ran between them to the top of the

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: steps. From there he called his balloon, which came to him at once- to the great

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: surprise of the boys in the gang.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: So Pascal and his balloon got home without being caught.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: The next day was Sunday. Before he left for church, Pascal told his balloon to

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: stay quietly at home, not to break anything, and especially not go out.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: But the balloon did exactly as it pleased. Pascal and his mother were hardly

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: seated in church when the balloon appeared and hung quietly in the air

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Now, a church is no place for a balloon. Everyone was looking at it and no one

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: was paying attention to the service. Pascal had to leave in a hurry, followed

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: out by the church guard. His balloon certainly had no sense of what was proper.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: All this worry had made him hungry. And as he still had his coin for the collec-

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: tion plate, he went into a bakeshop for some cake. Before he went inside he

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: said to the balloon: "Now be good and wait for me. Don't go away."

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: The balloon was good, and only went as far as the corner of the shop to warm

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: itself in the sun. But that was already too far. For the gang of boys who had

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: tried to catch it the day before saw it, and they thought that was the

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: moment to try again. Without being seen they crept up to it, jumped on it and

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: When Pascal came out of the bakeshop, there was no balloon! He ran in every

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: direction, looking up at the sky. The balloon had disobeyed him again! It had

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: gone off by itself! And although he called at the top of his voice, the balloon

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: The gang had tied the balloon to a strong string, and they were trying to teach

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: it tricks. "We could show this magic balloon in a circus," one of them said. He

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: shook a stick at the balloon. "Come here or I'll burst you," he shouted.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: As luck would have it, Pascal saw the balloon over the top of a wall, desper-

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: ately dragging at the end of its heavy string. He called to it.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: As soon as it heard his voice, the balloon flew toward him. Pascal quickly

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: untied the string and ran off with his balloon as fast as he could run.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: The boys raced after them. They made so much noise that everyone in the

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: neighborhood stopped to watch the chase. It seemed as if Pascal had stolen

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: the boys' balloon. Pascal thought: "I'll hide in the crowd." But a red balloon can

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: be seen anywhere, even in a crowd.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Pascal ran through narrow alleys, trying to lose the gang of boys.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: At one point the boys didn't know whether Pascal had turned right or left, so

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: they split up into several groups. For a minute Pascal thought he had escaped

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: them, and he looked around for a place to rest. But as he rounded a corner he

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: bumped right into one of the gang. He ran back the way he had come, but

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: there were more boys there. He was desperate - he ran up a side street which

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: led to an empty lot. He thought he'd be safe there.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: But suddenly boys appeared from every direction, and Pascal was surrounded.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: So he let go of his balloon. But this time, instead of chasing the balloon, the gang

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: attacked Pascal. The balloon flew a little way off, but when it saw Pascal fight-

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: ing it came back. The boys began throwing stones at the balloon.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: "Fly away, balloon! Fly away!" Pascal cried. But the balloon would not leave

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Then one of the stones hit the balloon, and it burst.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: While Pascal was crying over his dead balloon, the strangest thing happened!

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: Everywhere balloons could be seen flying up into the air and forming a line

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: It was the revolt of all captive balloons!

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: And all the balloons of Paris came down to Pascal, dancing around him,

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: twisting their strings into one strong one and lifting him up into the sky.

title: THE RED BALLOON
author: ALBERT LAMORISSE
text: And that was how Pascal took a wonderful trip all around the world.

title: ALLIGATOR PIE
author: DENNIS LEE
text: If I don't get some I think I'm gonna die.

title: ALLIGATOR PIE
author: DENNIS LEE
text: Give away the green grass, give away the sky,

title: ALLIGATOR PIE
author: DENNIS LEE
text: But don't give away my alligator pie.

title: ALLIGATOR PIE
author: DENNIS LEE
text: If I don't get some I don't know what I'll do.

title: ALLIGATOR PIE
author: DENNIS LEE
text: Give away my furry hat, give away my shoe,

title: ALLIGATOR PIE
author: DENNIS LEE
text: But don't give away my alligator stew.

title: ALLIGATOR PIE
author: DENNIS LEE
text: If I don't get some I think I'm gonna droop.

title: ALLIGATOR PIE
author: DENNIS LEE
text: Give away my hockey stick, give away my hoop,

title: ALLIGATOR PIE
author: DENNIS LEE
text: But don't give away my alligator soup.

title: CHUGGA-CHUGGA CHOO-CHOO
author: KEVIN LEWIS
text: Through the valleys, low and deep.

title: CHUGGA-CHUGGA CHOO-CHOO
author: KEVIN LEWIS
text: See the darkness. Hear the sound.

title: CHUGGA-CHUGGA CHOO-CHOO
author: KEVIN LEWIS
text: Across the river, swift and wide.

title: CHUGGA-CHUGGA CHOO-CHOO
author: KEVIN LEWIS
text: A bridge goes to the other side.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: He knocked on the front door.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: The snow is melting. Wake up!'

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: 'I am not here,' said the voice.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: from the corner of the room.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: He had pulled all the covers

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: Frog pushed Toad out of bed.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: He pushed him out of the house

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: Toad blinked in the bright sun.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: is the clear warm light of April.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: a whole new year together, Toad.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: In the evenings we will sit

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: right here on this front porch

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: said Toad. 'I will be too tired.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: I am going back to bed.'

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: Toad went back into the house.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: Come back again and wake me up

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: The November page was still on top.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: Frog tore off the November page.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: He tore off the December page.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: He came to the April page.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: Frog tore off the April page too.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: Then Frog ran back to Toad's bed.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: 'Toad, Toad, wake up. It is May now.'

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: The may page was on top.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: as he climbed out of the bed.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: even for a frog,' said Toad.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: Toad made Frog a cup of hot tea.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: Frog drank the tea, and then he said,

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: 'Tell me a story while I am resting.'

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: 'Let me think of a story to tell you.'

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: But he could not think of a story

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: 'I will go out on the front porch

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL
text: and walk up and down,' said Toad.

title: FROG AND TOAD
author: ARNOLD LOBEL

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: 'Now where in the world is that poky

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: little puppy?' they wondered. For he

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: certainly wasn't on top of the hill.

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: He wasn't going down the other side.

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: The only thing they could see going down

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: He wasn't coming up this side. The only

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: thing they could see coming up was a

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: But when they looked down at the grassy

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: place near the bottom of the hill, there he

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: was, looking hard at something on the

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: 'What is he doing?' the four little puppies

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: asked one another. And down they went

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: till they came to the green grass; and there

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: 'What in the world are you doing?' they

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: 'I see something!' said the poky little

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: The four little puppies looked, and they

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: could see it, too. It was a ripe, red strawberry

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: And home they went as fast as they could

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: go, over the bridge, up the road, through

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: the meadow, and under the fence. And

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: there, sure enough, was dinner waiting for

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: them, with strawberry shortcake for dessert.

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: But their mother said: 'So you're the little

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: puppies who dug that hole under the fence

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: again! No strawberry shortcake for supper

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: tonight!' And she made them go straight

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: But the four little puppies waited till

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: they thought she was asleep, and then they

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: slipped out and filled up the hole, and when

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: they turned around, there was their mother

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: And this time, when the poky little puppy

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: got home, he had to squeeze in through a

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: wide place in the fence. And there were his

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: four brother and sisters, licking the last

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: pity you're so poky! Now the strawberry

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: So the poky little puppy had to go to bed

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: without a single bite of shortcake, and he

title: THE POKY LITTLE PUPPY
author: JANETTE SEBRING LOWRY
text: And the next morning, someone had put

author: SANDRA MAGSAMEN
text: We'll rock you to sleep as we sing you

title: WELCOME LITTLE ONE
author: SANDRA MAGSAMEN
text: a song. We'll read you stories

title: WELCOME LITTLE ONE
author: SANDRA MAGSAMEN
text: We'll show you the beauty of

text: O.K, Sam. O.K., Mat. O.K., Cat.

title: BOB BOOKS, SET 1: BEGINNING READERS
author: BOBBY LYNN MASLEN
text: Dot has a dog. Dog has a hat.

title: BOB BOOKS, SET 1: BEGINNING READERS
author: BOBBY LYNN MASLEN
text: Dog has on a rag hat.

author: BOBBY LYNN MASLEN
text: Mac had a bag and a dog.

author: BOBBY LYNN MASLEN
text: Dot and Mit sit on a mat.

title: BOB BOOKS, SET 1: BEGINNING READERS
author: BOBBY LYNN MASLEN
text: Dot is hot. Mit is hot.

title: BOB BOOKS, SET 1: BEGINNING READERS
author: BOBBY LYNN MASLEN
text: Dot had a dog. The dog is Mag.

author: BOBBY LYNN MASLEN
text: Mag got the bag. Dot got Mag.

title: BOB BOOKS, SET 1: BEGINNING READERS
author: BOBBY LYNN MASLEN
text: Dot got Mag and the bag.

title: BOB BOOKS, SET 1: BEGINNING READERS
author: BOBBY LYNN MASLEN
text: The bag had a hot dog.

title: BOB BOOKS, SET 1: BEGINNING READERS
author: BOBBY LYNN MASLEN
text: Did Jig win? Did Mag win?

title: BOB BOOKS, SET 1: BEGINNING READERS
author: BOBBY LYNN MASLEN
text: Muff and Ruff tug a rag rug.

title: BOB BOOKS, SET 1: BEGINNING READERS
author: BOBBY LYNN MASLEN
text: Muff and Mac sat on it.

author: BOBBY LYNN MASLEN
text: A rag rug is fun for

title: JUST ME AND MY DAD
author: MERCER MAYER
text: I picked the campsite, but someone

title: JUST ME AND MY DAD
author: MERCER MAYER
text: and my dad lit the fire.

title: JUST ME AND MY DAD
author: MERCER MAYER
text: I wanted to take my dad

title: JUST ME AND MY DAD
author: MERCER MAYER
text: for a ride in our canoe,

title: JUST ME AND MY DAD
author: MERCER MAYER
text: but I launched it too hard.

title: JUST ME AND MY DAD
author: MERCER MAYER
text: After dinner, I told my dad a ghost story.

title: JUST ME AND MY DAD
author: MERCER MAYER
text: I gave my dad a big hug.

title: JUST ME AND MY DAD
author: MERCER MAYER
text: We slept in our tent all night long-

title: I LOVE YOU, STINKY FACE
author: LISA MCCOURT
text: "I love you, my wonderful child," said Mama as she tucked me in.

title: I LOVE YOU, STINKY FACE
author: LISA MCCOURT
text: Mama, what if I were a big, scary ape? Would still love me then?

title: I LOVE YOU, STINKY FACE
author: LISA MCCOURT
text: But Mama, but Mama, what if I were a super

title: I LOVE YOU, STINKY FACE
author: LISA MCCOURT
text: smelly skunk, and I smelled so bad that my name was

title: I LOVE YOU, STINKY FACE
author: LISA MCCOURT
text: But, Mama, but Mama what if I were an alligator

title: I LOVE YOU, STINKY FACE
author: LISA MCCOURT
text: with big, sharp teeth that could bite your head off?

title: I LOVE YOU, STINKY FACE
author: LISA MCCOURT
text: But Mama, what if I were a terrible

title: I LOVE YOU, STINKY FACE
author: LISA MCCOURT
text: meat-eating dinosaur with razor-sharp claws that ripped

title: I LOVE YOU, STINKY FACE
author: LISA MCCOURT
text: my sheets to shreds every night while I slept?

title: I LOVE YOU, STINKY FACE
author: LISA MCCOURT
text: to eat, if that is what

title: I LOVE YOU, STINKY FACE
author: LISA MCCOURT
text: But Mama, but Mama, what if I were a

title: I LOVE YOU, STINKY FACE
author: LISA MCCOURT
text: swamp creature with slimy, smelly seaweed hanging from my body,

title: I LOVE YOU, STINKY FACE
author: LISA MCCOURT
text: and I couldn't ever leave the swamp or I would die?

title: I LOVE YOU, STINKY FACE
author: LISA MCCOURT
text: And when you splashed to the

title: I LOVE YOU, STINKY FACE
author: LISA MCCOURT
text: "And I love you, my wonderful child."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: To lay this book in your lap.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Say it's just what you wanted?

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Because it's yours- Because we love you.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: If you happen to have read another book about Christopher Robin, you may

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: remember that he once had a swan (or the swan had Christopher Robin, I don't

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: know which) and that he used to call this swan Pooh. That was a long time ago,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and when we said good-bye, we took the name with us, as we didn't think the swan

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: would want it any more. Well, when Edward Bear said that he would like an

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: exciting name all to himself, Christopher Robin said at once, without stopping

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: to think, that he was Winnie-the.Pooh. And he was. So, as I have explained the

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh part, I will now explain the rest of it.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: You can't be in London for long

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: without going to the Zoo. There are some people who begin the Zoo at the

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: beginning, called WAYIN, and walk as quickly as they can past every cage

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: until they get to the one called WA YOUT, but the nicest people go straight

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: to the animal they love the most, and stay there. So when Christopher Robin

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: goes to the Zoo, he goes to where the Polar Bears are, and he whispers

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: something to the third keeper from the left, and doors are unlocked, and we

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: wander through dark passages and up steep stairs, until at last we come to

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: the special cage, and the cage is opened, and out trots something brown and

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: furry, and with a happy cry of "Oh, Bear!" Christopher Robin rushes into its

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: arms. Now this bear's name is Winnie, which shows what a good name for bears

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: it is, but the funny thing is that we can't remember whether Winnie is called

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: after Pooh, or Pooh after Winnie. We did know once, but we have

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: forgotten. . . . I had written as far as this when Piglet looked up and said

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: in his squeaky voice, "What about Me?" "My dear Piglet," I said, "the whole

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: book is about you." "So it is about Pooh," he squeaked. You see what it is.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He is jealous because he thinks Pooh is having a Grand Introduction all to

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
