text: himself. Pooh is the favorite, of course, there's no denying it, but Piglet

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: comes in for a good many things which Pooh misses; because you can't take

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh to school without everybody knowing it, but Piglet is so small that he

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: slips into a pocket, where it is very comfortable to feel him when you are

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: not quite sure whether twice seven is twelve or twenty-two. Sometimes he

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: slips out and has a good look in the ink-pot, and in this way he has got more

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: education than Pooh, but Pooh doesn't mind. Some have brains, and some haven't,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: he says, and there it is.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And now all the others are saying, "What about Us?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So perhaps the best thing to do is to stop writing Introductions and get on

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: We Are Introduced to Winnie-the-Pooh and Some Bees, and the Stories Begin

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: ERE IS Edward Bear, coming downstairs now, bump, bump, bump, on the back of

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: his head, behind Christopher Robin. It is, as far as he knows, the only way of

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: coming downstairs, but sometimes he feels that there really is another way, if

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: only he could stop bumping for a moment and think of it. And then he feels that

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: perhaps there isn't. Anyhow, here he is at the bottom, and ready to be

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: When I first heard his name, I said, just

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: as you are going to say, "But I thought he was a boy?" "So did I," said

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Then you can't call him Winnie?" "don't."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Ah, e, now I do," I said quickly; and I hope you do too, because it is all

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: the explanation you are going to get.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Sometimes Winnie-the-Pooh likes a game of

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: some sort when he comes downstairs, and sometimes he likes to sit quietly in

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: front of the fire and listen to a story. This evening-.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "What about a story?" said Christopher Robin.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Could you very sweetly tell Winnie-the-Pooh one?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: I suppose I could," I said.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "What sort of stories does he like?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "About himself. Because he's that sort of Bear." "Oh, I see." "So could you

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: very sweetly?" ''I'll try," I said. So I tried.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Once upon a time, a very long

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: time ago now, about last Friday, Winnie-the-Pooh lived in a forest all by

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: himself under the name of Sanders.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: ("What does 'under the name' mean)" asked Christopher Robin. "It means he had

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: the name over the door in gold letters, and lived under it."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Winnie-the-Pooh wasn't quite sure," said Christopher Robin.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Then I will go on," said I.)

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: One day when he was out walking, he came to an

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: open place in the middle of the forest, and in the

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: middle of this place was a large oak-tree, and, from

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: the top of the tree, there came a loud buzzing-

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Winnie-the-Pooh sat own at the foot of the

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: tree, put his head between his paws and began to

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: First of all he said to himself: "That buzzing-noise

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: means something. You don't get a buzzing noise like

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: that, just buzzing and buzzing, without its meaning

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: something. If there's a buzzing -noise, somebody's

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: making a buzzing-noise, and the only reason for making

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: a buzzing-noise that I know of is because you're a bee."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Then he thought another long time, and said:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "And the only reason for being a bee that I know of is making honey."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And then he got up, and said: "And the only reason for making honey is so as

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So he began to climb the tree.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and a little further...and then just a little further. By that time

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: he had thought of another song.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: It's a very funny thought that, if Beas were Bees,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: They'd build their nests at the bottom of trees.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And that being so (if the Bees were Bears),

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: We shouldn't have to climb up all these stairs.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He was getting rather tired by this time, so that is why he sang a Complaining

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Song.He was nearly there now, and if he just stood on that branch...

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh, help!" said Pooh, as he dropped ten feet on the branch below him.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "If only I hadn't--" he said, as he bounced

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: twenty feet on to the next branch. "You see, what I meant to do,"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: as he turned head-over-heels, and crashed on to another branch thirty feet

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Of course, it was rather--" he admitted, as he slithered very quickly

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It all comes, I suppose," he decided, as he said good-bye to the last branch,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: spun round three times, and flew gracefully into a gorse-bush,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "it all comes of liking honey so much. Oh, help!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He crawled out of the gorse-bush, brushed the prickles from his nose,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and began to think again. And the first person he thought of was Christopher

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: ("Was that me?" said Christopher Robin in an awed voice, hardly daring to

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: believe it. h  was you. "Christopher Robin said nothing, but his eyes got

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: larger and larger, and his face got pinker and pinker.)

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So Winnie-the-Pooh went round to his friend Christopher Robin, who lived

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: behind a green door in another part of the forest.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I wonder if you've got such a thing as a balloon about you?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Yes, I just said myself coming along: 'I wonder

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: if Christopher Robin has such a thing as a balloon about him?' I just said it

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: to myself, thinking of balloons, and wondering."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "What do you want a balloon for?" you said.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Winnie-the-Pooh looked around to see that nobody was listening, put his paw

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: to his mouth, and said in a deep whisper: "Honey!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Well , it just happened that you had been to a party

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: the day before at the house of your friend Piglet, and

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: you had balloons at the party. You had had a big green balloon; and one of

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: a big blue one, and had left it behind,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: being really too young to go to a party at all; and so you had brought the

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: green one and the blue one home with you.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Which one would you like"you asked

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He put his head between his paws and thought very carefully.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It's like this," he said. "When you go after honey

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: the great thing is not to let the bees know you're coming. Now, if you have a

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: green balloon, they might think you were only part of the tree, and not notice

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: you, and if you have a blue balloon, they might think you were only part of the

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: sky, and not notice you, and the question is: Which is most likely?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Wouldn't they notice you underneath the balloon?" you asked.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "They might or they might not, said Winnie-the.Pooh. "You never can tell with

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: bees." He thought for a moment and said: "I shall try to look like a small black

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Then you had better have the blue balloon," you said; and so it was decided.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Well, you both went out with the blue balloon, and you took your gun

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: just in case, as you al.ways did, and Winnie -the-Pooh went to a very muddy

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: place that he knew of, and rolled and rolled until he was black all over;

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and then, when the balloon was blown up as big as big, and you and Pooh were

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: both holding on to the string, you let go suddenly, and Pooh Bear floated

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: gracefully up into the sky, and stayed there -level with the top of the tree

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and about twenty feet away from it.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Isn that fine?" shouted Winnie-the-Pooh down to you.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You look like a Bear holding on to a balloon," you said.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Not-" said Pooh anxiously, "-not like a small black cloud in a blue sky?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Ah, well, perhaps from up here it looks different. And, as I say, you never

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: There was no wind to blow him nearer to the tree, so there he stayed.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He could see the honey, he could smell the honey, but he couldn't quite reach

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: After a little while he called down to you.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Christopher Robin!" he said in a loud whisper.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I don't know. But something tells me that they're suspicious!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Perhaps they think that you're after their honey."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It may be that. You never can tell with bees."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: There was another little silence, and then he called down to you again.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Have you an umbrella in your house?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I wish you would bring it out here, and walk up and down with it, and look up

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: me every now and then, and say 'Tut-tut, it looks like rain'. I think if you

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: did that, it would help the deception which we are practicing on these bees."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well, you laughed to yourself", "Silly old Bear!" but you didn't say it aloud

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: because you were so found of him, and you went home for your umbrella.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh, there you are!" called down Winnie-the.Pooh, as soon as you got back to

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I was beginning to get anxious. I have discovered that the bees are now

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Shall I put my umbrella up?" you said.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Yes, but wait a moment. We must be practical. The important bee to deceive is

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: the Queen Bee. Can you see which is the Queen Bee from down there?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "A pity. Well, now, if you walk up and down with your umbrella, saying,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: 'Tut-tut, it looks like rain,' I shall do what I can by singing a little Cloud

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Song, such as a cloud might sing .... Go!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "So, while you walked up and down and wondered if it would rain, Winnie-the-Pooh

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: How sweet to be a Cloud

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: The bees were still buzzing as suspiciously as ever. Some of them, indeed,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: left their nest and flew all round the cloud as it began the second verse of

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: this song and one bee sat down on the nose of the cloud

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Christopher-- ow!-- Robin," called out the cloud.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I have just been thinking, and I have come to very important decision. These

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: are the wrong sort of bees."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Quite the wrong sort. So I should think they would make the wrong sort of

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Yes. So I think I shall come down."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Winnie-the-Pooh hadn't thought about this. If he let go of the string, he would

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: fall--bump--and he didn't like the idea of that. So he thought for a long time,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and then he said: "Christopher Robin, you must shoot the balloon with your gun.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Of course I have," you said. "But if I do that, it will spoil the balloon,"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "But if you don't," said Pooh, "I shall have to let go, and that would spoil me.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: When you put it like this, you saw how it was, and you aimed very carefully at

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You didn't exactly miss," said Pooh, "but you missed the balloon."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I'm so sorry" you said, and you fired again, and this time you hit the balloon,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and the air came slowly out, and Winnie-the-Pooh floated down to the ground.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: But his arms were so stiff from holding on to the string of the balloon all that

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: time that they stayed up straight in the air for more than a week, and whenever

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: a fly came and settled on his nose he had to blow it off. And I think--but I am

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: not sure--that that is why he was always called Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Is that the end of the story?" asked Christopher Robin.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "That's the end of that one. There are others."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "And Piglet and Rabbit and all of you. Don't you remember?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I do remember, and then when I try to remember , I forget."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "That day when Pooh and Piglet tried to catch the Heffalump --"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Pooh couldn't, because he hasn't any brain. Did I catch it?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I do remember," he said, "only Pooh doesn't very well, so that's why he likes

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: having it told to him again. Because then it's a real story and not just a

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "That's just how I feel," I said.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Christopher Robin gave a deep sigh, picked his Bear up by the leg, and walked

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: off to the door, trailing Pooh behind him. At the door he turned and said,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Coming to see me have my bath?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I didn't hurt him when I shot him, did I?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He nodded and went out, and in a moment I heard Winnie-the-Pooh--bump, bump,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: bump-- going up the stairs behind him."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: In Which Pooh Goes Visiting and Gets Into a Tight Place

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: EDWARD BEAR, known to his friends as Winnie-the-Pooh, or Pooh for short, was walking through the forest one day, humming proudly to himself. He had made up a little hum that very morning, as he was doing his Stoutness Exercises in front of the glass: Tra-la-la, tra-la-la, as he stretched up as high as he could go, and then Tra-la-la, tra-la - oh, help! - la, as he tried to reach his toes. After breakfast he had said it over and over to himself until he had learnt it off by heart, and now he was humming it right through, properly. It went like this:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Tra-la-la, tra-la-la, Tra-la-la, tra-la-la, Rum-tum-tiddle-um-tum, Tiddle-iddle, tiddle-iddle, Tiddle-iddle, tiddle-iddle, Rum-tum-tum-tiddle-um.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Well, he was humming this hum to himself, and walking along gaily, wondering what everybody else was doing, and what it felt like, being somebody else, when suddenly he came to a sandy bank, and in the bank was a large hole.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Aha!" said Pooh. (Rum-tum-tiddle-um-tum.) "If I know anything about anything, that hole means Rabbit," he said, "and Rabbit means Company," he said, "and Company means Food and Listening-to-Me Humming and such like. Rum-tum-tum-tiddle-um."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So he bent down, put his head into the hole, and called out: "Is anybody at home?" There was suddenly a scuffling noise from inside the hole, and then silence. "What I said was, 'Is anybody at home?'" called out Pooh very loudly.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "No!" said a voice; and then added, "you needn't shout so loud. I heard you quite well the first time."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Bother!" said Pooh. "Isn't there anybody here at all?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Winnie-the-Pooh took his head out of the hole, and thought for a little, and he thought to himself, "There must be somebody there, because somebody must have said 'Nobody.'" So he put his head back in the hole, and said: "Hallo, Rabbit, isn't that you?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "No" said Rabbit, in a different sort of voice this time.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I don't think so," said Rabbit. "It isn't meant to be."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh!" said Pooh. He took his head out of the hole, and had another think, and then he put it back, and said: "Well, could you very kindly tell me where Rabbit is?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "He has gone to see his friend Pooh Bear, who is a great friend of his."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "But this is Me!" said Bear, very much surprised.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Are you sure?" said Rabbit, still more surprised.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh, well, then, come in." So Pooh pushed and pushed and pushed his way through the hole, and at last he got in. "You were quite right," said Rabbit, looking at him all over. "It is you. Glad

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well, I wasn't sure. You know how it is in the Forest. One can't have anybody coming into one's house. One has to be careful. What about a mouthful of something?" Pooh always liked a little something at eleven o'clock in the morning, and he was very glad to see Rabbit getting out the plates and mugs; and when Rabbit said, "Honey or condensed milk with your bread?" he was so excited that he said, "Both," and then, so as not to seem greedy, he added, "but don't bother about the bread, please." And for a long time after that he said nothing ... until at last, humming to himself in a rather sticky voice, he got up, shook Rabbit lovingly by the paw, and said that he must be going on.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well," said Pooh, "I could stay a little longer if it - if you -" and he tried very hard to look in the direction of the larder.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "As a matter of fact," said Rabbit, "I was going out myself directly."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh, well, then, I'll be going on. Good-bye."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well, good-bye, if you're sure you won't have anymore."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Is there any more?" asked Pooh quickly.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Rabbit took the covers off the dishes, and said no, there wasn't.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I thought not," said Pooh, nodding to himself. "Well, good-bye. I must be going on." So he started to climb out of the hole. He pulled with his front paws, and pushed with his back paws, and in a little while his nose was out in the open again ... and then his ears ... and then his front paws ... and then his shoulders ... and then - "Oh, help!" said Pooh. "I'd better go back." "Oh, bother" said Pooh. "I shall have to go on." "I can't do either!" said Pooh. "Oh, help and bother!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Now by this time Rabbit wanted to go for a walk too, and finding the front door full, he went out by the back door, and came round to Pooh, and looked at him. "Hallo, are you stuck?" he asked.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "N-no," said Pooh carelessly. "Just resting and thinking and humming to myself."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh Bear stretched out a paw, and Rabbit pulled and pulled and pulled... "Ow!" cried Pooh. "You're hurting!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It all comes," said Pooh crossly, "of not having front doors big enough."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It all comes," said Rabbit sternly, "of eating too much. I thought at the time," said Rabbit, "only I didn't like to say anything," said Rabbit, "that one of us was eating too much," said Rabbit, "and I knew it wasn't me," he said. "Well, well, I shall go and fetch Christopher Robin."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Christopher Robin lived at he other end of the Forest, and when he came back with Rabbit, and saw the front half of Pooh, he said, "Silly old Bear," in such a loving voice that everybody felt quite hopeful again.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I was just beginning to think," said Bear, sniffing slightly, "that Rabbit might never be able to use his front door again. And I should hate that," he said.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Use his front door again?" said Christopher Robin. "Of course he'll use his front door again."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "If we can't pull you out, Pooh, we might push you back."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Rabbit scratched his whiskers thoughtfully, and pointed out that, when once Pooh was pushed back, he was back, and of course nobody was more glad to see Pooh than he was, still there it was, some lived in trees and some lived underground, and -

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You mean I'd never get out?" said Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I mean," said Rabbit, "that having got so far, it seems a pity to waste it."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "There's only one thing to be done," he said. "We shall have to wait for you to get thin again."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "How long does getting thin take?" asked Pooh anxiously.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "But I can't stay here for a week!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You can stay here all right, silly old Bear. It's getting you out which is so difficult."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "We'll read to you," said Rabbit cheerfully. "And I hope it won't snow," he added. "And I say, old fellow, you're taking up a good deal of room in my house - do you mind if I use your back legs as a towel-horse? Because, I mean, there they are - doing nothing - and it would be very convenient just to hang the towels on them."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "A week!" said Pooh gloomily. "What about meals?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I'm afraid no meals," said Christopher Robin, "because of getting thin quicker. But we will read to you."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Bear began to sigh, and then found he couldn't because he was so tightly stuck; and a tear rolled down his eye, as he said: "Then would you read a Sustaining Book, such as would help and comfort a Wedged Bear in Great Tightness?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So for a week Christopher Robin read that sort of book at the North end of Pooh, and Rabbit hung his washing on the South end... and in between Bear felt himself getting slenderer and slenderer. And at the end of the week Christopher Robin said, "Now!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So he took hold of Pooh's front paws and Rabbit took hold of Christopher Robin, and all Rabbit's friends and relations took hold of Rabbit, and they all pulled together...

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And for a long time Pooh only said "Ow!"... And "Oh!"... And then, all of a sudden, he said "Pop!" just as if a cork were coming out of a bottle.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And Christopher Robin and Rabbit and all Rabbit's friends and relations went head-over-heels backwards ... and on the top of them came Winnie-the-Pooh - free! So, with a nod of thanks to his friends, he went on with his walk through the forest, humming proudly to himself. But, Christopher Robin looked after him lovingly, and said to himself, "Silly old Bear!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: In Which Pooh and Piglet Go Hunting and Nearly Catch a Woozle

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: THE PIGLET lived in a very grand house in the middle of a a beech-tree, and the beech-tree was in the middle of the forest, and the Piglet lived in the middle of the house. Next to his house was a piece of broken board which had: "TRESPASSERS W" on it. When Christopher Robin asked the Piglet what it meant, he said it was his grandfather's name, and had been in the family for a long time. Christopher Robin said you couldn't be called Trespassers W, and Piglet said yes, you could, because his grandfather was, and it was short for Trespassers Will, which was short for Trespassers William. And his grandfather had had two names in case he lost one - Trespassers after an uncle, and William after Trespassers.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I've got two names," said Christopher Robin carelessly.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well, there you are, that proves it," said Piglet. One fine winter's day when Piglet was brushing away the snow in front of his house, he happened to look up, and there was Winnie-the-Pooh. Pooh was walking round and round in a circle, thinking of something else, and when Piglet called to him, he just went on walking.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "That's just what I ask myself. I ask myself, What?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I shall have to wait until I catch up with it," said Winnie-the-Pooh. "Now, look there." He pointed to the ground in front of him. "What do you see there?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Tracks," said Piglet. "Paw-marks." He gave a little squeak of excitement. "Oh, Pooh! Do you think it's a - a - a Woozle?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It may be," said Pooh. "Sometimes it is, and sometimes it isn't. You can never tell with paw-marks."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: With these few words he went on tracking, and Piglet, after watching him for a minute or two, ran after him. Winnie-the-Pooh had come to a sudden stop, and was bending over the tracks in a puzzled sort of way.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It's a very funny thing," said Bear, "but there seem to be two animals now. This - whatever-it-was - has been joined by another - whatever-it-is - and the two of them are now proceeding in company. Would you mind coming with me, Piglet, in case they turn out to be Hostile Animals?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Piglet scratched his ear in a nice sort of way, and said that he had nothing to do until Friday, and would be delighted to come, in case it really was a Woozle.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You mean, in case it really is two Woozles," said Winnie-the-Pooh, and Piglet said that anyhow he had nothing to do until Friday. So off they went together.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: There was a small spinney of larch trees just here, and it seemed as if the two Woozles, if that is what they were, had been going round this spinney; so round this spinney went Pooh and Piglet after them, Piglet passing the time by telling Pooh what his Grandfather Trespassers W had done to Remove Stiffness after Tracking, and how his Grandfather Trespassers W had suffered in his later years from Shortness of Breath, and other matters of interest, and Pooh wondering what a Grandfather was like, and if perhaps this was Two Grandfathers they were after now, and, if so, whether he would be allowed to take one home and keep it, and what Christopher Robin would say. And still the tracks went on in front of them...

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Suddenly Winnie-the-Pooh stopped and pointed excitedly in front of him. "Look!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "What?" said Piglet, with a jump. And then, to show that he hadn't been frightened, he jumped up and down once or twice in an exercising sort of way.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "The tracks!" said Pooh. "A third animal has joined the other two!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Pooh!" cried Piglet. "Do you think it is another Woozle?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "No," said Pooh, "because it makes different marks. It is either Two Woozles and one, as it might be, Wizzle, or Two, as it might be, Wizzles and one, if so it is, Woozle. Let us continue to follow them."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So they went on, feeling just a little anxious now, in case the three animals in front of them were of Hostile Intent. And Piglet wished very much that his Grandfather T. W. were there, instead of elsewhere, and Pooh thought how nice it would be if they met Christopher Robin suddenly but quite accidentally, and only because he liked Christopher Robin so much. And then, all of a sudden, Winnie-the-Pooh stopped again, and licked the tip of his nose in a cooling manner, for he was feeling more hot and anxious than ever in his life before. There were four animals in front of them!

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Do you see, Piglet? Look at their tracks! Three, as it were, Woozles, and one, as it was, Wizzle. Another Woozle has joined them!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And so it seemed to be. There were the tracks; crossing over each other here, getting muddled up with each other there; but, quite plainly every now and then, the tracks of four sets of paws.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I think," said Piglet, when he had licked the tip of his nose too, and found that it brought very little comfort, "I think that I have just remembered something. I have just remembered something that I forgot to do yesterday and shan't be able to do tomorrow. So I suppose I really ought to go back and do it now."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "We'll do it this afternoon, and I'll come with you," said Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It isn't the sort of thing you can do in the afternoon," said Piglet quickly. "It's a very particular morning thing, that has to be done in the morning, and, if possible, between the hours of - What would you say the time was?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "About twelve," said Winnie-the-Pooh, looking at the sun.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Between, as I was saying, the hours of twelve and twelve five. So, really, dear old Pooh, if you'll excuse me - What's that?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh looked up at the sky, and then, as he heard the whistle again, he looked up into the branches of a big oak-tree, and then he saw a friend of his.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Ah, then you'll be all right," said Piglet. "You'll be quite safe with him. Good-bye," and he trotted off home as quickly as he could, very glad to be Out of All Danger again.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Christopher Robin came slowly down his tree.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Silly old Bear," he said, "what were you doing? First you went round the spinney twice by yourself, and then Piglet ran after you and you went round again together, and then you were just going round a fourth time -"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Wait a moment," said Winnie-the-Pooh, holding up his paw.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He sat down and thought, in the most thoughtful way he could think. Then he fitted his paw into one of the Tracks ... and then he scratched his nose twice, and stood up.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I have been Foolish and Deluded," said he, "and I am a Bear of No Brain at All."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You're the Best Bear in All the World," said Christopher Robin soothingly.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Am I?" said Pooh hopefully. And then he brightened up suddenly.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Anyhow," he said, "it is nearly Luncheon Time." So he went home for it.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: In Which Eeyore Loses a Tail and Pooh Finds One

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: The old grey donkey, Eeyore, stood by himself in a thistly corner of the forest, his front feet well apart, his head on one side, and thought about things. Sometimes he thought sadly to himself, "Why?" and sometimes he thought, "Wherefore?" and sometimes he thought, "Inasmuch as which?" - and sometimes he didn't quite know what he was thinking about. So when Winnie-the-Pooh came stumping along, Eeyore was very glad to be able to stop thinking for a little, in order to say "How do you do?" in a gloomy manner to him.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Eeyore shook his head from side to side. "Not very how," he said. "I don't seem to have felt at all how for a long time."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Dear, dear," said Pooh, "I'm sorry about that. Let's have a look at you."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So Eeyore stood there, gazing sadly at the ground, and Winnie-the-Pooh walked all round him once. "Why, what's happened to your tail?" he said in surprise.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "What has happened to it?" said Eeyore.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well, either a tail is there or it isn't there. You can't make a mistake about it. And yours isn't there!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Let's have a look," said Eeyore, and he turned slowly round to the place where his tail had been a little while ago, and then, finding that he couldn't catch it up, he turned round the other way, until he came back to where he was at first, and then he put his head down and looked between his front legs, and at last he said, with a long, sad sigh, "I believe you're right."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "That Accounts for a Good Deal," said Eeyore gloomily. "It Explains Everything. No Wonder."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You must have left it somewhere," said Winnie-the-Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Somebody must have taken it," said Eeyore. "How Like Them," he added, after a long silence.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh felt that he ought to say something helpful about it, but didn't quite know what. So he decided to do something helpful instead.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Eeyore," he said solemnly, "I, Winnie-the-Pooh, will find your tail for you."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Thank you, Pooh," answered Eeyore. "You're a real friend," said he. "Not like Some," he said.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So Winnie-the-Pooh went off to find Eeyore's tail. It was a fine spring morning in the forest as he started out. Little soft clouds played happily in a blue sky, skipping from time to time in front of the sun as if they had come to put it out, and then sliding away suddenly so that the next might have his turn. Through them and between them the sun shone bravely; and a copse which had worn its firs all the year round seemed old and dowdy now beside the new green lace which the beeches had put on so prettily. Through copse and spinney marched Bear; down open slopes of gorse and heather, over rocky beds of streams, up steep banks of sandstone into the heather again; and so at last, tired and hungry, to the Hundred Acre Wood. For it was in the Hundred Acre Wood that Owl lived.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "And if anyone knows anything about anything," said Bear to himself, "it's Owl who knows something about something," he said, "or my name's not Winnie-the-Pooh," he said. "Which it is," he added. "So there you are."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Owl lived at The Chestnuts, an old-world residence of great charm, which was grander than anybody else's, or seemed so to Bear, because it had both a knocker and a bell-pull. Underneath the knocker there was a notice which said: PLES RING IF AN RNSER IS REQIRD.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Underneath the bell-pull there was a notice which said: PLEZ CNOKE IF AN RNSR IS NOT REQID.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: These notices had been written by Christopher Robin, who was the only one in the forest who could spell; for Owl, wise though he was in many ways, able to read and write and spell his own name WOL, yet somehow went all to pieces over delicate words like MEASLES and BUTTERED TOAST.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Winnie-the-Pooh read the two notices very carefully, first from left to right, and afterwards, in case he had missed some of it, from right to left. Then, to make quite sure, he knocked and pulled the knocker, and he pulled and knocked the bell-rope, and he called out in a very loud voice, "Owl! I require an answer! It's Bear speaking."" And the door opened, and Owl looked out.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Terrible and Sad," said Pooh, "because Eeyore, who is a friend of mine, has lost his tail. And he's Moping about it. So could you very kindly tell me how to find it for him?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well," said Owl, "the customary procedure in such cases is as follows."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "What does Crustimoney Proseedcake mean?" said Pooh. "For I am a Bear of Very Little Brain, and long words Bother me."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "As long as it means that, I don't mind," said Pooh humbly.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "The thing to do is as follows. First, Issue a Reward. Then -"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Just a moment," said Pooh, holding up his paw.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "What do we do to this - what you were saying? You sneezed just as you were going to tell me."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Excuse me, Pooh, I didn't. You can't sneeze without knowing it."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well, you can't know it without something having been sneezed."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "What I said was, 'First Issue a Reward.'"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You're doing it again," said Pooh sadly.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "A Reward!" said Owl very loudly. "We write a notice to say that we will give a large something to anybody who finds Eeyore's tail."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I see, I see," said Pooh, nodding his head. "Talking about large somethings," he went on dreamily, "I generally have a small something about now - about this time in the morning," and he looked wistfully at the cupboard in the corner of Owl's parlour; "just a mouthful of condensed milk or what not, with perhaps a lick of honey -"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well, then," said Owl, "we write out this notice, and we put it up all over the forest."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "A lick of honey," murmured Bear to himself, "or - or not, as the case may be." And he gave a deep sigh, and tried very hard to listen to what Owl was saying.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: But Owl went on and on, using longer and longer words, until at last he came back to where he started, and he explained that the person to write out this notice was Christopher Robin.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It was he who wrote the ones on my front door for me. Did you see them, Pooh?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: For some time now Pooh had been saying "Yes" and "No" in turn, with his eyes shut, to all that Owl was saying, and having said, "Yes, yes," last time, he said "No, not at all," now, without really knowing what Owl was talking about.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Didn't you see them?" said Owl, a little surprised. "Come and look at them now."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So they went outside. And Pooh looked at the knocker and the notice below it, and he looked at the bell-rope and the notice below it, and the more he looked at the bell-rope, the more he felt that he had seen something like it, somewhere else, sometime before.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It reminds me of something," he said, "but I can't think what. Where did you get it?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I just came across it in the Forest. It was hanging over a bush, and I thought at first somebody lived there, so I rang it, and nothing happened, and then I rang it again very loudly, and it came off in my hand, and as nobody seemed to want it, I took it home, and -"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Owl," said Pooh solemnly, "you made a mistake. Somebody did want it."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Eeyore. My dear friend Eeyore. He was - he was fond of it."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So with these words he unhooked it, and carried it back to Eeyore; and when Christopher Robin had nailed it on in its right place again, Eeyore frisked about the forest, waving his tail so happily that Winnie-the-Pooh came over all funny, and had to hurry home for a little snack of something to sustain him. And, wiping his mouth half an hour afterwards, he sang to himself proudly:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I," said Pooh, "At a quarter to two

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: (Only it was quarter to eleven really),

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: ONE DAY, when Christopher Robin and Winnie-the-Pooh and Piglet were all talking together, Christopher Robin finished the mouthful he was eating and said carelessly: "I saw a Heffalump to-day, Piglet."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Just lumping along," said Christopher Robin. "I don't think it saw me."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I saw one once," said Piglet. "At least, I think I did," he said. "Only perhaps it wasn't."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "So did I," said Pooh, wondering what a Heffalump was like.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You don't often see them," said Christopher Robin carelessly.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Not at this time of year," said Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Then they all talked about something else, until it was time for Pooh and Piglet to go home together. At first as they stumped along the path which edged the Hundred Acre Wood, they didn't say much to each other' but when they came to the stream and had helped each other across the stepping stones, and were able to walk side by side again over the heather, they began to talk in a friendly way about this and that, and Piglet said,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "If you see what I mean, Pooh," and Pooh said,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It's just what I think myself, Piglet," and Piglet said,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "But, on the other hand, Pooh, we must remember," and Pooh said

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Quite true, Piglet, although I had forgotten it for the moment."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And then, just as they came to the Six Pine Trees, Pooh looked round to see that nobody else was listening, and said in a very solemn voice:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I have decided to catch a Heffalump."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh nodded his head several times as he said this, and waited for Piglet to say "How?" or "Pooh, you couldn't" or something helpful of that sort, but Piglet said nothing. The fact was Piglet was wishing that he had thought about it first.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I shall do it," said Pooh, after waiting a little longer, "by means of a trap. And it must be a Cunning Trap, so you will have to help me, Piglet."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Pooh," said Piglet, feeling quite happy again now, "I will."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And then he said, "How shall we do it?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And Pooh said, "That's just it. How?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And then they sat down together to think it out.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh's first idea was that they should dig a Very Deep Pit, and then the Heffalump would come along and fall into the Pit, and-

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh rubbed his nose with his paw, and said that the Heffalump might be walking along, humming a little song, and looking up at the sky, wondering if it would rain, and so he wouldn't see the Very Deep Pit until he was half-way down, when it would be too late.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Piglet said that this was a very good Trap, but supposing it were raining already?

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh rubbed his nose again, and said that he hadn't thought of that. And then he brightened up, and said that, if it were raining already, the Heffalump would be looking at the sky wondering if it would clear up, and so he wouldn't see the Very Deep Pit until he was half-way down...¦. When it would be too late.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Piglet said that, now that this point had been explained, he thought it was a Cunning Trap.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh was very proud when he heard this, and he felt that the Heffalump was as good as caught already, but there was just one other thing which had to be thought about, and it was this. Where should they dig the Very Deep Pit?

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Piglet said that the best place would be somewhere where a Heffalump was, just before he fell into it, only about a foot farther on.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "But then he would see us digging it," said Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Not if he was looking at the sky."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "He would suspect," said Pooh, "if he happened to look down."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He thought for a long time and then added sadly, "It isn't as easy as I thought. I suppose that's why Heffalumps hardly ever get caught."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: They sighed and got up; and when they had taken a few gorse prickles out of themselves they sat down again' and all the time Pooh was saying to himself, "If only I could think of something!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: For he felt sure that a Very Clever Brain could catch a Heffalump if only he knew the right way to go about it.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Suppose," he said to Piglet, "you wanted to catch me, how would you do it?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well," said Piglet, "I should do it like this. I should make a Trap, and I should put a Jar of Honey in the Trap, and you would smell it, and you would go in after it, and-"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "And I would go in after it," said Pooh excitedly, "only very carefully so as not to hurt myself, and I would get to the Jar of Honey, and I should lick round the edges first of all, pretending that there wasn't any more, you know, and then I should walk away and think about it a little, and then I should come back and start licking in the middle of the jar, and then-"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Yes, well never mind about that. There you would be, and there I should catch you. Now the first thing to think of is, What do Heffalumps like? I should think acorns, shouldn't you? We'll get a lot of-I say, wake up, Pooh!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh, who had gone into a happy dream, woke up with a start, and said that Honey was a much more trappy thing than Haycorns. Piglet didn't think so; and they were just going to argue about it, when Piglet remembered that, if they put acorns in the Trap, he would have to find the acorns, but if they put honey, then Pooh would have to give up some of his own honey, so he said, "All right, honey then," just as Pooh remembered it too, and was going to say, "All right, haycorns."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Honey," said Piglet to himself in a thoughtful way, as if it were now settled.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I'll dig the pit, while you go and get the honey."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Very well," said Pooh, and he stumped off.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: As soon as he got home, he went to the larder; and he stood on a chair, and took down a very large jar of honey from the top shelf. It had HUNNY written on it, but, just to make sure, he took off the paper cover and looked at it, and it looked just like honey.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "But you never can tell," said Pooh. "I remember my uncle saying once that he had seen cheese just this colour."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So he put his tongue in, and took a large lick.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Yes," he said, "it is. No doubt about that. And honey, I should say, right down to the bottom of the jar. Unless, of course," he said "somebody put cheese in at the bottom just for a joke. Perhaps I had better go a little further...¦ just in case...¦ in case Heffalumps don't like cheese...¦ same as me...¦Ah!" And he gave a deep sigh. "I was right. It is honey, right the way down."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Having made certain of this, he took the jar back to Piglet, and Piglet looked up from the bottom of his Very Deep Pit, and said "Got it?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and Pooh said, "Yes, but it isn't quite a full jar," and he threw it down to Piglet, and Piglet said

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "No, it isn't! Is that all you've got left?" and Pooh said

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Because it was. So Piglet put the jar at the bottom of the Pit, and climbed out, and they went off home together.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well, good night, Pooh," said Piglet, when they had got to Pooh's house. "And we meet at six o'clock tomorrow morning by the Pine Trees, and see how many Heffalumps we've got in out Trap."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Six o'clock, Piglet. And have you got any string?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh!... I think Heffalumps come if you whistle."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Some do and some don't. You never can tell with Heffalumps. Well, good night!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And off Piglet trotted to his house, TRESPASSERS W, while Pooh made his preparations for bed.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Some hours later, just as the night was beginning to steal away, Pooh woke up suddenly with a sinking feeling. He had had that sinking feeling before, and he knew what it meant. He was hungry. So he went to the larder, and he stood on a chair and reached up to the top shelf, and found-nothing.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "That's funny," he thought. "I know I had a jar of honey there. A full jar, full of honey right up to the top, and it had HUNNY written on it, so that I should know it was honey. That's very funny." And then he began to wander up and down, wondering where it was and murmuring a murmur to himself.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: 'Cos I know I had some honey;

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And I don't know where it's gone to,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: No I don't know where it's gone-

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He had murmured this to himself three times in a singing sort of way, when suddenly he remembered. He had put it into the Cunning Trap to catch the Heffalump.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Bother!" said Pooh. "It all comes of trying to be kind to Heffalumps." And he got back into bed.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: But he couldn't sleep. The more he tried to sleep, the more he couldn't He tried Counting Sheep, which is sometimes a good way of getting to sleep, and, as that was no good, he tried counting Heffalumps. And that was worse. Because every Heffalump that he counted was making straight for a pot of Pooh's honey, and eating it all. For some minutes he lay there miserably, but when the five hundred and eighty-seventh Heffalump was licking its jaws, and saying to itself, "Very good honey this, I don't know when I've tasted better," Pooh could bear it no longer. He jumped out of bed, he ran out of the house, and he ran straight to the Six Pine Trees.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: The Sun was still in bed, but there was a lightness in the sky over the Hundred Acre Wood which seemed to show that it was waking up and would soon be kicking off the clothes. In the half-light the Pine Trees looked cold and lonely, and the Very Deep Pit seemed deeper than it was, and Pooh's jar of honey at the bottom was something mysterious, a shape and no more. But as he got nearer to it his nose told him that it was indeed honey, and his tongue came out and began to polish up his mouth, ready for it.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Bother!" said Pooh, as he got his nose inside the jar. "A Heffalump has been eating it!" And then he thought a little and said, "Oh, no, I did. I forgot."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Indeed, he had eaten most of it. But there was a little left at the very bottom of the jar, and he pushed his head right in, and began to lick...¦.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: By and by Piglet woke up. As soon as he woke up he said to himself, "Oh!" Then he said bravely, "Yes," and then, still more bravely, "Quite so." But he didn't feel very brave at all, for the word which was really jiggeting about in his brain was "Heffalumps."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Did it come when you whistled? And how did it come?

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Was it Fond of Pigs at all?

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: If it was Fond of Pigs, did it make any difference what sort of Pig?

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Supposing it was Fierce with Pigs, would it make any difference if the Pig had a grandfather called TRESPASSERS WILLIAM?

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He didn't know the answer to any of these questions...¦ and he was going to see his first Heffalump in about an hour from now!

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Of course Pooh would be with him, and it was much more Friendly with two. But suppose Heffalumps were Very Fierce with Pigs and Bears? Wouldn't it be better to pretend that he had a headache, and couldn't go up to the Six Pine Trees this morning? But then suppose that it was a very fine day, and there was no Heffalump in the trap, here he would be, in bed all the morning, simply wasting his time for nothing. What should he do?

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And then he had a Clever Idea. He would go up very quietly to the Six Pine Trees now, peep very cautiously into the Trap, and see if there was a Heffalump there. And if there was, he would go back to bed, and if there wasn't, he wouldn't.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So off he went. At first he thought that there wouldn't be a Heffalump in the Trap, and then he thought that there would, because he could hear it heffalumping about it like anything.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh, dear, oh, dear, oh, dear!" said Piglet to himself. And he wanted to run away. But somehow, having got so near, he felt that he must just see what a Heffalump was like. So he crept to the side of the Trap and looked in...¦.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And all the time Winnie-the-Pooh had been trying to get the honey-jar off his head. The more he shook it, the more tightly it stuck. "Bother!" he said inside the jar, and "Oh, help!" and, mostly "Ow!" And he tried bumping it against things, but as he couldn't see what he was bumping it against, it didn't help him; and he tried to climb out of the Trap, but as he could see nothing but jar, and not much of that, he couldn't find his way. So at last he lifted up his head, jar and all, and made a loud, roaring noise of Sadness and Despair...¦ and it was at that moment that Piglet looked down.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Help, help!" cried Piglet, "a Heffalump, a Horrible Heffalump!" and he scampered off as hard as he could, still crying out, "Help, help, a Herrible Hoffalump! Hoff, Hoff, a Hellible Horralump! Holl, Holl, a Hoffable Hellerump!" And he didn't stop crying and scampering until he got to Christopher Robin's house.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Whatever's the matter, Piglet?" said Christopher Robin, who was just getting up.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Heff," said Piglet, breathing so hard that he could hardly speak, "a Hell- a Heff- a Heffalump."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Up there," said Piglet, waving his paw.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Like- like- It had the biggest head you ever saw, Christopher Robin. A great enormous thing, like- like nothing. A huge big- well, like a- I don't know- like an enormous big nothing. Like a jar."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well," said Christopher Robin, putting on his shoes, "I shall go and look at it. Come on."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Piglet wasn't afraid if he had Christopher Robin with him, so off they went...¦.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I can hear it, can't you?" said Piglet anxiously, as they got near.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I can hear something," said Christopher Robin.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: It was Pooh bumping his head against a tree-root he had found.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "There!" said Piglet. "Isn't it awful?" And he held on tight to Christopher Robin' hand.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Suddenly Christopher Robin began to laugh...¦ and he laughed...¦ and he laughed...¦ and he laughed. And while he was still laughing- Crash went the Heffalump's head against the tree-root, Smash went the jar, and out came Pooh's head again...¦.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Then Piglet saw what a Foolish Piglet he had been, and he was so ashamed of himself that he ran straight off home and went to bed with a headache. But Christopher Robin and Pooh went home to breakfast together.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh, Bear!" said Christopher Robin. "How I do love you!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Eeyore Has a Birthday and Gets Two Presents

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: EYORE, the old grey Donkey, stood by the side of

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: the stream, and looked at himself in the water.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Pathetic ," he said. "That's what it is. Pathetic."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: e turned and walked slowly down the stream for twenty yards, splashed across it,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and walked slowly back on the other side. Then he looked at himself in

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "As I thought," he said. "No better from this side.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: But nobody minds. Nobody cares. Pathetic, that's

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: what it is." There was a crackling noise in the bracken behind

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: him, and out came Pooh. "Good morning, Eeyore," said Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Good morning, Pooh Bear," said Eeyore gloomily. "If it is a good morning," he said. "Which I

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Nothing, Pooh Bear, nothing. We can't all, and

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: some of us don't. That's all there is to it."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Can't all what?" said Pooh, rubbing his nose.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Gaiety. Song-and-dance . Here we go round the

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh!" said Pooh. He thought for a long time, and

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: then asked, "What mulberry bush is that?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: word meaning bonhommy," he explained. "I'm not

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh sat down on a large stone, and tried to think

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: this out. It sounded to him like a riddle, and he was

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: never much good at riddles, being a Bear of Very

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Little Brain . So he sang Cottleston Pie instead:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: A fly can't bird, but a bird can fly.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Ask me a riddle and I reply:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: That was the first verse. When he had finished it,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Eeyore didn't actually say that he didn't like it, so

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh very kindly sang the second verse to him:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: A fish can't whistle and neither can I.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Ask me a riddle and I reply:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Eeyore still said nothing at all, so Pooh hummed

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: the third verse quietly to himself:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Why does a chicken, I don't know why.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Ask me a riddle and I reply:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: umty -too. Here we go gathering Nuts and May.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Sad?  Why should I be sad? It's my birthday. The

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Your birthday?" said Pooh in great surprise.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Of course it is. Can't you see? Look at all the

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: presents I have had." He waved a foot from side to

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: side. "Look at the birthday cake. Candles and pink

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh looked- first to the right and then to the

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Neither can I," said Eeyore. "Joke," he explained. "Ha ha!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh scratched his head, being a little puzzled by all this.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "But is it really your birthday?" he asked.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Oh! Well, Many happy returns of the day,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "And many happy returns to you, Pooh Bear."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well why not? You don't always want to be

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: miserable on my birthday, do you?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It's bad enough, said Eeyore, almost breaking

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: down, "being miserable myself, what with no pres-

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: ents and no cake and no candles, and no proper no-

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: tice taken of me at all, but if everybody else is going

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: This was too much for Pooh. "Stay there!" he

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: called to Eeyore, as he turned and hurried back home

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: as quick as he could; for he felt that he must get poor

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Eeyore a present of some sort at once, and he could

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: always think of a proper one afterwards.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Outside his house he found Piglet, jumping up and

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: down trying to reach the knocker.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I was trying to reach the knocker," said Piglet. "I

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Let me do it for you," said Pooh kindly. So he

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: reached up and knocked at the door. "I have just seen

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Eeyore," he began, "and poor Eeyore is in a Very

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Sad Condition, because it's his birthday, and nobody

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: has taken any notice of it, and he's very Gloomy-

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: you know what Eeyore is- and there he was, and

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: --What a long time whoever lives here is answer-

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: ing this door." And he knocked again.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "But Pooh," said Piglet, "it's your own house!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh!" said Pooh. "So it is," he said. "Well, let's

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So in they went. The first thing Pooh did was to go

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: to the cupboard to see if he had quite a small jar of

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: honey left; and he had, so he took it down.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I'm giving this to Eeyore," he explained, "as a

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: present. What are you going to give?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Couldn't I give it too?" said Piglet. "From both

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "No," said Pooh, "That would not be a good

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "All right, then, I'll give him a balloon. I've got

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: one left from my party. I'll go and get it now

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "That, Piglet, is a very good idea. It is just what

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Eeyore wants to cheer him up. Nobody can be un-

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So off Piglet trotted; and in the other direction

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: went Pooh, with his jar of honey.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: It was a warm day, and he had a long way to go.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He hadn't gone more than half-way when a sort of

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: funny feeling began to creep all over him. It began

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: at the tip of his nose and trickled all through him

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and out at the soles of his feet. It was just as if somebody inside him were saying, "Now then, Pooh, time

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Dear, dear," said Pooh, "I didn't know it was as

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: late as that." So he sat down and took the top off his

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: jar of honey. "Lucky I brought this with me," he

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: thought. "Many a bear going out on a warm day like

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: this would never have thought of bringing a little

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: something with him." And he began to eat.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Now let me see," he thought, as he took his last

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: lick of the inside of the jar, "where was I going? Ah,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: yes, Eeyore." He got up slowly.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And then, suddenly, he remembered. He had

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Bother!" said Pooh. "What shall I do? I must give

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: For a little while he couldn't think of anything.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Then he thought: "Well, it's a very nice pot, even if

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: there's no honey in it, and if I washed it clean, and

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: got somebody to write 'A Happy Birthday' on it,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Eeyore could keep things in it, which might be Useful."  So, as he was just passing the Hundred Acre

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Wood, he went inside to call on Owl, who lived there.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Many happy returns of Eeyore's  birthday," said

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I'm giving him a Useful Pot to Keep Things In,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and I wanted to ask you --

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Is this it?" said Owl, taking it out of Pooh's paw.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Yes, and I wanted to ask you--"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Somebody has been keeping honey in it," said

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You can keep anything in it," said Pooh earnestly.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It's Very Useful like that. And I wanted to ask

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You ought to write 'A Happy Birthday' on it."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: That was what I wanted to ask you," said Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Because my spelling is Wobbly. It's good spelling

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: but it Wobbles, and the letters get in the wrong

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: places. Would you write 'A Happy Birthday' on it for

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It's a nice pot," said Owl, looking at it all round.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Could't I give it too? From both of us?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "No," said Pooh. "That would not be a good plan.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Now I'll just wash it first, and then you can write on

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Well, he washed the pot out, and dried it, while

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Owl licked the end of his pencil, and wondered how

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Can you read, Pooh?" he asked, a little anxiously.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "There's a notice about knocking and ringing outside

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: my door, which Christopher Robin wrote. Could you

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Christopher Robin told me what it said, and then

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Well, I'll tell you what this says, and then you'll

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So Owl wrote... and this is what he wrote:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I'm just saying 'A Happy Birthday,'" said Owl

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It's a nice long one," said Pooh, very much impressed by it. "Well, actually, of course, I'm saying 'A Very

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Happy Birthday with love from Pooh.' Naturally it

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: takes a good deal of pencil to say a long thing like that."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: While all this was happening, Piglet had gone back

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: to his own house to get Eeyore's balloon. He held it

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: very tightly against himself, so that it shouldn't blow

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: away, and he ran as fast as he could so as to get to

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Eeyore before Pooh did; for he thought that he

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: would like to be the first one to give a present, just

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: as if he had thought of it without being told by any-

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: body. And running along, and thinking how pleased

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Eeyore would be, he didn't look where he was

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: going ... and suddenly he put his foot in a rabbit

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: hole, and fell down flat on his face.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Piglet lay there, wondering what had happened. At

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: first he thought that the whole world had blown up;

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and then he thought that perhaps only the Forest part

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: of it had; and then he thought that perhaps only he

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: had, and he was now alone in the moon or some-

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: where, and would never see Christopher Robin or

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh or Eeyore again. And then he thought, "Well,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: even if I'm in the moon, I needn't be face downwards all the time," so he got cautiously up and

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He was still in the Forest!

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well, that's funny," he thought. "I wonder what
