title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: that bang was. I couldn't have made such a noise just

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: falling down. And where's my balloon? And what's

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: that small piece of damp rag doing?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh dear!" said Piglet. "Oh, dear, oh, dearie,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: dearie, dear! Well, it's too late now. I can't go back,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and I haven't another balloon, and perhaps Eeyore

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: doesn't like balloons so very much."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So he trotted on, rather sadly now, and down he

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: came to the side of the stream where Eeyore was, and

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Good morning, Little Piglet," said Eeyore. "If it

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: is a good morning," he said. "Which I doubt," said

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: he. "Not that it matters," he said.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Many happy returns of the day," said Piglet, having now got closer.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Eeyore stopped looking at himself in the stream,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and turned to stare at Piglet.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Balancing on three legs, he began to bring his

author: A.A. MILNE
text: fourth leg very cautiously up to his ear. "I did this

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: yesterday, " he explained, as he fell down for the third

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: time. "It's quite easy. It's so as I can hear better.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: ...There, that's done it! Now then, what were you

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: saying?" He pushed his ear forward with his hoof.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Many happy returns of the day," said Piglet again.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Yes, Eeyore, and I've brought you a present."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Eeyore took down his right hoof from his right ear,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: turned round, and with great difficulty put up his left

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I must have that in the other ear," he said. "Now

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Me going on having a real birthday?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Yes, Eeyore, and I brought you a balloon."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: One of those big coloured things you blow up? Gaiety, song-and-dance, here we are and there we are?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Yes, but I'm afraid- I'm very sorry, Eeyore-

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: but when I was running along to bring it you, I fell

author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Dear, dear, how unlucky! You ran too fast, I ex-

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: pect. You didn't hurt yourself, Little Piglet?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: No, but I-I-oh, Eeyore, I burst the balloon!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: There was a very long silence.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: My balloon? said Eeyore at last.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Yes, Eeyore," said Piglet sniffing a little. "Here it

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: is. With- with many happy returns of the day." And

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: he gave Eeyore the small piece of damp rag.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Is this it?" said Eeyore, a little surprised.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: mind my asking," he went on, "but what colour was

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: this balloon when it- when it was a balloon?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I just wondered.... Red," he murmured to him-

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: self. "My favourite colour . . .. How big was it?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I just wondered .... About as big as Piglet," he

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: said to himself sadly. "My favourite size. Well, well."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Piglet felt very miserable, and didn't know what to

author: A.A. MILNE
text: say. He was still opening his mouth to begin some-

author: A.A. MILNE
text: thing, and then deciding that it wasn't any good say-

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: ing that, when he heard a shout from the other side of

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: the river, and there was Pooh.

author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Many happy returns of the day," called out Pooh,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: forgetting that he had said it already.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Thank you, Pooh, I'm having them," said Eeyore

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I've brought you a little present," said Pooh excitedly.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: ooh had now splashed across the stream to

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Eeyore, and Piglet was sitting a little way off, his head

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: in his paws, snuffling to himself.

title: WINNIE THE POOH

text: "It's a Useful Pot," said Pooh. "Here it is. And it's

author: A.A. MILNE
text: got 'A Very Happy Birthday with love from Pooh'

title: WINNIE THE POOH

text: written on it. That's what all that writing is. And it's

text: When Eeyore saw the pot, he became quite excited.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Why!" he said. "I believe my Balloon will just go

author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh no, Eeyore," said Pooh. "Balloons are much

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: too big to go into Pots. What you do with a balloon

text: And as Piglet looked sorrowfully round, Eeyore

text: picked the balloon up with his teeth, and placed it

text: carefully in the pot; picked it out and put it on the

author: A.A. MILNE
text: "So it does!" said Piglet. "And it comes out!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Doesn't it?" said Eeyore. "It goes in and out like

author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I'm very glad," said Pooh happily, "that I thought

author: A.A. MILNE
text: of giving you a Useful Pot to put things in."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I'm very glad," said Piglet happily, "that I

title: WINNIE THE POOH

text: thought of giving you Something to put in a Useful

text: But Eeyore wasn't listening. He was taking the balloon out, and putting it back again, as happy as could

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "And didn't I give him anything?" asked Christopher Robin sadly.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Of course you did," I said. "You gave him-don't you remember- a little- a little --"

title: WINNIE THE POOH

text: "I gave him a box of paints to paint things with."

title: WINNIE THE POOH

text: "Why didn't I give it to him in the morning?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You were so busy getting his party ready for him. He had a cake with icing on the top, and three candles, and his name in pink sugar, and--"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Kanga and Baby Roo Come to the Forest, and Piglet Has a Bath

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: OBODY seemed to know here they came from, but there they were in the Forest: Kanga and Baby Roo. When Pooh asked Christopher Robin, "How did they come here?" Christopher Robin said, "In the Usual Way, if you know what I mean, Pooh," and Pooh, who didn't, said "Oh!" Then he nodded his head twice and said, "In the Usual Way. Ah!" Then he went to call upon his friend Piglet to see what he thought about it. And at Piglet's house he found Rabbit. So they all talked about it together.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "What I don't like about it is this," said Rabbit. "Here are we- you, Pooh, and you, Piglet, and Me- and suddenly--"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "And Owl- and then all of a sudden --"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh, and Eeyore," said Pooh. "I was forgetting him."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Here-we-are," said Rabbit very slowly and carefully, "all-of-us, and then, suddenly, we wake up one morning and, what do we find? We find a Strange Animal among us. An animal of whom we have never even heard before! An animal who carries her family about with her in her pocket! Suppose I carried my family about with me in my pocket, how many pockets should I want?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Seventeen, isn't it?" said Rabbit. "And one more for a handkerchief-that's eighteen. Eighteen pockets in one suit! I haven't time."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: There was a long and thoughtful silence ... and then Pooh, who had been frowning very hard for some minutes, said: "I make it fifteen."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh rubbed his nose and said that he thought Rabbit had been talking about his family.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "The question is, What are we to do about Kanga?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "The best way," said Rabbit, "would be this. The best way would be to steal Baby Roo and hide him, and then when Kanga says, 'Where's Baby Roo?' we say, Aha!'"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Aha!" said Pooh, practising. "Aha! Aha!... Of course," he went on, "we could say 'Aha!' even if we hadn't stolen Baby Roo."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Pooh," said Rabbit kindly, "you haven't any brain."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "We say 'Aha!' so that Kanga knows that we know where Baby Roo is. 'Aha!' means 'We'll tell you where Baby Roo is, if you promise to go away from the Forest and never come back.' Now don't talk while I think."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh went into a corner and tried saying "Aha!" in that sort of voice. Sometimes it seemed to him that it did mean what Rabbit said, and sometimes it seemed to him that it didn't.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I suppose it's just practice," he thought. "I wonder if Kanga will have to practise too so as to understand it."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "There's just one thing" said Piglet, fidgeting a bit. "I was talking to Christopher Robin, and he said that a Kanga was Generally Regarded as One of the Fiercer Animals. I am not frightened of Fierce Animals in the ordinary way, but it is well known that, if One of the Fiercer Animals is Deprived of Its Young, it becomes as fierce as Two of the Fiercer Animals. In which case 'Aha!' is perhaps a foolish thing to say."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Piglet" said Rabbit, taking out a pencil, and licking the end of it, "you haven't any pluck."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It is hard to be brave," said Piglet, sniffing slightly, "when you're only a Very Small Animal."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Rabbit, who had begun to write very busily, looked up and said:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It is because you are a very small animal that you will be Useful in the adventure before us."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Piglet was so excited at the idea of being Useful that he forgot to be frightened any more, and when Rabbit went on to say that Kangas were only Fierce during the winter months, being at other times of an Affectionate Disposition, he could hardly sit still, he was so eager to begin being useful at once.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "What about me?" said Pooh sadly. "I suppose I shan't be useful?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Never mind, Pooh" said Piglet comfortingly. "Another time perhaps."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Without Pooh," said Rabbit solemnly as he sharpened his pencil, "the adventure would be impossible."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh!" said Piglet, and tried not to look disappointed.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: But Pooh went into a corner of the room and said proudly to himself, "Impossible without Me! That sort of Bear."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Now listen all of you" said Rabbit when he had finished writing, and Pooh and Piglet sat listening very eagerly with their mouths open. This was what Rabbit read out:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: 1. General Remarks. Kanga runs faster than any of Us, even Me.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: 2. More General Remarks. Kanga never takes her eye off Baby Roo, except when he's safely buttoned up in her pocket.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: 3. Therefore. If we are to capture Baby Roo, we must get a Long Start, because Kanga runs faster than any of Us, even Me. (See 1.)

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: 4. A Thought. If Roo had jumped out of Kanga's pocket and Piglet had jumped in, Kanga wouldn't know the difference, because Piglet is a Very Small Animal.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: 6. But Kanga would have to be looking the other way first, so as not to see Piglet jumping in.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: 8. Another Thought. But if Pooh was talking to oher very excitedly, she might look the other way for a moment.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: 9. And then I could run away with Roo.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: 11. And Kanga wouldn't discover the difference until After-wards.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Well, Rabbit read this out proudly, and for a little while after he had read it nobody said anything. And then Piglet, who had been opening and shutting his mouth without making any noise, managed to say very huskily:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Nothing," said Piglet, "As long as we all three say it. As long as we all three say it," said Piglet, "I don't mind," he said, "but I shouldn't care to say 'Aha!' by myself. It wouldn't sound nearly so well. By the way," he said, "you are quite sure about what you said about the winter months?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Yes, only being Fierce in the Winter Months."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh, yes, yes, that's all right. Well, Pooh? You see what you have to do?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "No," said Pooh Bear. "Not yet," he said. "What do I do?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well, you just have to talk very hard to Kanga so as she doesn't notice anything."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You mean like telling her a little bit of poetry or something?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "That's it," said Rabbit. "Splendid. Now come along."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So they all went out to look for Kanga.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Kanga and Roo were spending a queit afternoon in a sandy part of the Forest. Baby Roo was practising very small jumps in the sand, and falling down mouse-holes and climbing out of them, and Kanga was fidgeting about and saying "Just one more jump, dear, and then we must go home. " And at that moment who should come stumping up the hill but Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Look at me jumping," squeaked Roo, and fell into another mouse-hole.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "We were just going home," said Kanga. "Good afternoon, Rabbit. Good afternoon, Piglet."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Rabbit and Piglet, who had now come up from the other side of the hill, said, "Good afternoon," and "Hallo, Roo," and Roo asked them to look at him jumping, so they stayed and looked.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh, Kanga," said Pooh, after Rabbit had winked at him twice, "I don't know if you are interested in Poetry at all?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Roo, dear, just one more jump and then we must go home."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: There was a short silence while Roo fell down another mouse-hole.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Go on," said Rabbit in a loud whisper behind his paw.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Talking of Poetry," said Pooh, "I made up a little piece as I was coming along. It went like this. Er-- now let me see--"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You'll like this piece of poetry," said Rabbit.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You must listen very carefully," said Rabbit.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "So as not to miss any of it," said Piglet.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh, yes," said Kanga, but she still looked at Baby Roo.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "How did it go, Pooh?" said Rabbit.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh gave a little cough and began.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: LINES WRITTEN BY A BEAR OF VERY LITTLE BRAIN

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: On Monday, when the sun is hot

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: I wonder to myself a lot:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Now is it true, or is it not,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "That what is which and which is what?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: On Tuesday, when it hails and snows,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: The feeling on me grows and grows

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: If those are these or these are those.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: On Wednesday, when the sky is blue,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And I have nothing else to do,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: I sometimes wonder if it's true

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: That who is what and what is who.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: On Thursday, when it starts to freeze

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And hoar-frost twinkles on the trees,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: That these are whose -but whose are these?

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Yes, it is, isn't it?" said Kanga, not waiting to hear what happened on Friday. "Just one more jump, Roo, dear, and then we really must be going."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Rabbit gave Pooh a hurrying-up sort of nudge.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Talking of Poetry," said Pooh quickly, "have you ever noticed that tree right over there?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Right over there," said Pooh, pointing behind K

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "No," said Kanga. "Now jump in, Roo, dear, and we'll go home."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You ought to look at that tree right over there," said Rabbit. "Shall I lift you in, Roo?" And he picked up Roo in his paws.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I can see a bird in it from here," said Pooh. "Or is it a fish?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You ought to see that bird from here," said Rabbit. "Unless it's a fish."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It isn't a fish, it's a bird," said Piglet.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Is it a starling or a blackbird?" said Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "That's a whole question," said Rabbit. "Is it a blackbird or a starling?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And then at last Kanga did turn her head to look. And the moment that her head was turned, Rabbit said in a loud voice "In you go, Roo!" and in jumped Piglet into Kanga's pocket, and off scampered Rabbit, with Roo in his paws, as fast as he could.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Why, where's Rabbit?" said Kanga, turning round again. "Are you all right, Roo, dear?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Piglet made a squeaky Roo-noise from the bottom of Kanga's pocket.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Rabbit had to go away," said Pooh. "I think he thought of something he had to go and see about suddenly."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I think Piglet thought of something at the same time. Suddenly."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well, we must be getting home," said Kanga. "Good-bye, Pooh." And in three large jumps she was gone.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh looked after her as she went.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I wish I could jump like that," he thought. "Some can and some can't. That's how it is."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: But there were moments when Piglet wished that Kanga couldn't. Often, when he had had a long walk home through the Forest, he had wished that he were a bird; but now he thought jerkily to himself at the bottom of Kanga's pocket,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "If this is flying I shall never really take to it."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And as he went up in the air, he said, "Ooooooo!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and as he came down he said, "Ow!" And he was saying, "Ooooooo-ow, Ooooooo-ow, Ooooooo-ow" all the way to Kanga's house.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Of course as soon as Kanga unbuttoned her pocket, she saw what had happened. Just for a moment, she thought she was frightened, and then she knew she wasn't; for she felt quite sure that Christopher Robin would never let any harm happen to Roo. So she said to herself, "If they are having a joke with me, I will have a joke with them."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Now then, Roo, dear," she said, as she took Piglet out of her pocket. "Bed-time."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Aha!" said Piglet, as well as he could after his Terrifying Journey. But it wasn't a very good "Aha!" and Kanga didn't seem to understand what it meant.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Aha! said Piglet again, looking round anxiously for the others. But the others weren't there. Rabbit was playing with Baby Roo in his own house, and feeling more fond of him every minute, and Pooh, who had decided to be a Kanga, was still at the sandy place on the top of the Forest, practising jumps.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I am not at all sure," said Kanga in a thoughtful voice, "that it wouldn't be a good idea to have a cold bath this evening. Would you like that, Roo, dear?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Piglet, who had never really been fond of baths,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: shuddered a long indignant shudder, and said in as brave a voice as he could:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Kanga, I see the time has come to speak plainly."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Funny little Roo," said Kanga, as she got the bathwater ready.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I am not Roo," said Piglet loudly. "I am Piglet!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Yes, dear, yes," said Kanga soothingly. "And imitating Piglet's voice too! So clever of him," she went on as she took a large bar of yellow soap out of the cupboard. "What will he be doing next?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Can't you see?" shouted Piglet. "Haven't you got eyes? Look at me!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I am looking, Roo, dear" said Kanga rather severely. "And you know what I told you yesterday about making faces. If you go on making faces like Piglet's, you will grow up to look like Piglet- and then think how sorry you will be. Now then, into the bath, and don't let me have to speak to you about it again."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Before he knew where he was, Piglet was in the bath, and Kanga was scrubbing him firmly with a large lathery flannel.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Ow!" cried Piglet."Let me out! I'm Piglet!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Don't open the mouth, dear, or the soap goes in," said Kanga. "There! What did I tell you?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You-you-you did it on purpose," spluttered Piglet, as soon as he could speak again ... and then accidentally had another mouthful of lathery flannel.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "That's right, dear, don't say anything,"" said Kanga, and in another minute Piglet was out of the bath, and being rubbed dry with a towel.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Now," said Kanga, "there's your medicine, and then bed."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "To make you grow big and strong, dear. You don't want to grow up small and weak like Piglet, do you? Well, then!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: At that moment there was a knock on the door.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Come in," said Kanga, and in came Christopher Robin.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Christopher Robin, Christopher Robin!" cried Piglet. "Tell Kanga who I am! She keeps saying I'm Roo. I'm not Roo, am I?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Christopher Robin looked at him very carefully, and shook his head. "You can't be Roo," he said, "because I've just seen Roo playing in Rabbit's house."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well!" said Kanga. "Fancy that! Fancy my making a mistake like that."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "There you are!" said Piglet. "I told you so. I'm Piglet."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Christopher Robin shook his head again.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh, you're not Piglet," he said. "I know Piglet well, and he's quite a different color."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Piglet began to say that this was because he had just had a bath, and then he thought that perhaps he wouldn't say that, and as he opened his mouth to say something else, Kanga slipped the medicine spoon in, and then patted him on the back and told him that it was really quite a nice taste when you got used to it.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I knew it wasn't Piglet," said Kanga."I wonder who it can be."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Perhaps it's some relation of Pooh's" said Christopher Robin. "What about a nephew or an uncle or something?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Kanga agreed that this was probably what it was, and said that they would have to call it by some name.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I shall call it Pootel," said Christopher Robin. "Henry Pootel for short."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And just when it was decided, Henry Pootel wriggled out of Kanga's arms and jumped to the ground. To his great joy Christopher Robin had left the door open. Never had Henry Pootel Piglet run so fast sa he ran then, and he didn't stop running until he had got quite close to his house. But when he was a hundred yards away he stopped running, and rolled the rest of the way home, so as to het his own nice comfortable colour again....

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So Kanga and Roo stayed in the Forest. And every Tuesday Roo spent the day with her great friend Pooh, teaching him to jump, and every Tuesday Piglet spent the day with his great friend Christopher Robin. So they were all happy again.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Christopher Robin Leads an Expotition to the North Pole

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: One fine day Pooh had stumped up to the top of the Forest to see if his friend Christopher Robin was interested in Bears at all. At breakfast that morning (a simple meal of marmalade spread lightly over a honeycomb or two) he had suddenly thought of a new song. It began like this:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Sing Ho! for the life of a Bear!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: When he had got as far as this, he stretched his head, and thought to himself "That's a very good start for a song, but what about the second line?" He tried singing "Ho," two or three times, but it didn't seem to help. "Perhaps it would be better," he thought, "if I sang Hi for the life of a Bear." So he sang it ... but it wasn't. "Very well, then," he said, "I shall sing that first line twice, and perhaps if I sing

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: it very quickly, I shall find myself singing the third and fourth lines before I have time to think of them, and that will be a Good Song. Now then:

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Sing Ho! For the life of a Bear!

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Sing Ho! for the life of a Bear!

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: I don't much mind if it rains or snows,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: 'Cos I've got a lot of honey on my nice

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: I don't much care if it snows or thaws, 'Cos I've got a lot of honey on my nice clean paws!

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And I'll have a little something in an hour or two!

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He was so pleased with this song chat he sang it all the way to the top of the Forest, "and if I go on singing it much longer," he thought, "it will be time for the little something, and then the last line won't be true." So he turned it into a hum instead.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Christopher Robin was sitting outside his door, putting on his Big Boots. As soon as he saw the Big

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Boots, Pooh knew that an Adventure was going to happen, and he brushed the honey off his nose with the back of his paw, and spruced himself up as well as he could, so as to look Ready for Anything.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Hallo, Pooh Bear. I can't get this boot on."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Do you think you could very kindly lean against me, 'cos I keep pulling so hard that I fall over backwards."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh sat down, dug his feet into the ground, and pushed hard against Christopher Robin's back, and Christopher Robin pushed hard against his, and pulled and pulled at his boot until he had got it on.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "And that's that," said Pooh. "What do we do next?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "We are all going on an Expedition," said Christopher Robin, as he got up and brushed himself. "Thank you, Pooh."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Going on an Expotition?" said Pooh eagerly. "I don't think I've ever been on one of those. Where are we going to on this Expotition?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Expedition, silly old Bear. It's got an 'x' in it." "Oh!" said Pooh. "] know." But he didn't really. "We're going to discover the North Pole."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh!" said Pooh again. "What is the North Pole?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It's just a thing you discover," said Christopher Robin carelessly, not being quite sure himself.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh! I see," said Pooh. "Are bears any good at

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Of course they are. And Rabbit and Kanga and all of you. It's an Expedition. That's what an Expedition means. A long line of everybody. You'd better tell the others to get ready, while I see if my gun's all right. And we must all bring Provisions."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh!" said Pooh happily. "I thought you said Provisions. I'll go and tell them." And he stumped off.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: The first person he met was Rabbit.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Let's pretend it isn't," said Rabbit, "and see what happens."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "We're all going on an Expotition with Christopher Robin!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "What is it when we'r eon it?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "A sort of boat, I think," said Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Yes. And we're going to discover a Pole or something. Or was it a Mole? Anyhow we're going to discoer it."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Yes. And we've got to bring Po- things to eat with us. In case we want to eat them. Now I'm going down to Piglet's. Tell Kanga, will you?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He left Rabbit and hurried down to Piglet's house. The Piglet was sitting on the ground at the door of his house blowing happily at a dandelion, and wondering whether it would be this year, next year, sometime or never. He had just discovered that it would be never, and was trying to remember what "it" was, and hoping it wasn't anything nice, when Pooh came up.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh! Piglet," said Pooh excitedly, "we're going on an Expotition, all of us, with things to eat. To discover something."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Christopher Robin didn't say anything about fierce. He just said it had an 'x'."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It isn't their necks I mind," said Piglet earnestly. "It's their teeth. But if Christopher Robin is coming I don't mind anything."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: In a little while they were all ready at the top of the Forest, and the Expotition started. First came Christopher Robin and RAbbit, then Piglet and Pooh; then Kanga, with Roo in her pocket, and Owl; then Eeyore; and, at the end, in a long line, all Rabbit's friends-and-relations.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I didn't ask them," explained Rabbit carelessly. "They just came. They always do. They can march at the end, after Eeyore."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "What I say," said Eeyore, "is that it's unsettling. I didn't want to come on this Epo- what Pooh said. I only came to oblige. But here I am; and if I am the end of the Expo- what we're talking about- then let me be the end. But if, every time I want to sit down for a little rest, I have to brush away half a dozen of Rabbit's smaller friends and relations first, then this isn't an Expo- whatever it is- at all, it's simply a Confused Noise. That's what I say."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I see what Eeyore means," said Owl. "If you ask me--"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I'm not asking anybody," said Eeyore. "I'm just telling everybody. We can look for the North Pole, or we can play 'Here we go gathering Nuts and May' with the end part of an ant's nest. It's all the same to me."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: There was a shout from the top of the line.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "We're starting," said Rabbit. "I must go." And he hurried off to the front of the expotition with Christopher Robin.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "All right," said Eeyore. "We're going. Only Don't Blame Me."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So off they all went to discover the Pole. And as they walked, they chattered to each other of this and that, all except Pooh, who was making up a song.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "This is the first verse," he said to Piglet, when he was ready with it.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well, if you listen, Piglet, you'll hear it."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "How do you know I'm not listening?

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh couldn't answer that one, so he began to sing.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: They all went off to discover the Pole,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Owl and Piglet and Rabbit and all;

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: It's a Thing you Discover, as I've been tole

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: By Owl and Piglet and Rabbit and all.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And Rabbit's relations all went too--

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And where the Pole was none of them knew....

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Sing Hey! for Owl and Rabbit and all!

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Hush!" said Christopher Robin turning round to Pooh, "we're just coming to a Dangerous Place."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Hush!" said Pooh turning round quickly to Piglet.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Hush!" said Kanga to Owl, while Roo said "Hush!" several times to himself very quietly.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Hush!" said Eeyore in a terrible voice to all Rabbit's friends -and -relations, and "Hush!" they said hastily to each other all down the line, until it got to the last one of all. And the last and smallest friend -and-relarion was so upset to find that the whole Expotitian was saying "Hush!" to him, that he buried himself head downwards in a crack in the ground,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and stayed there for two days until the danger was over, and then went home in a great hurry, and lived quietly with his Aunt ever- afterwards. His name was Alexander Beetle.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: They had come to a stream which twisted and tumbled between high rocky banks, and Christopher robin saw at once how dangerous it was.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It's just the place," he explained, "for an Ambush."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "What sort of bush?" whispered Pooh to Piglet. "A gorse bush?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "My dear Pooh," said Owl in his superior way, "don't you know what an Ambush is?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Owl," said Piglet, looking round at him severely, "Pooh's whisper was a perfectly private whisper, and there was no need--"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "An ambush," said Owl, "is a sort of Surprise."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "So is a gorse-bush sometimes" said Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "An Ambush, as I was about to explain to Pooh," said Piglet, "is a sort of Surprise."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "If people jump out at you suddenly, that's an Ambush," said Owl.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It's an Ambush, Pooh, when people jump at you suddenly," explained Piglet.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh, who now knew what an Ambush was, said that a gorse-bush had sprung at him suddenly one day when he fell off a tree, and he had taken six days to get all the prickles out of himself.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "We are not talking about gorse-bushes." said Owl a little crossly.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: They were climbing very cautiously up the stream now, going from rock to rock, and after they had gone a little way they came to a place where the banks widened out at each side, so that on each side of the water there was a level strip of grass on which they could sit down and rest. As soon as he saw this, Christopher Robin called "Halt!" and they all sat down and rested.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I think," said Christopher Tobin, "that we ought to eat all our Provisions now, so that we shan't have so much to carry."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "All that we've brought," said Piglet, getting to work.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "That's a good idea," said Pooh, and he got to work too.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Have you all got something?" asked Christopher Robin with his mouth full.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "All except me," said Eeyore. "As Usual." He looked around at him in his melancholy way. "I suppose none of you are sitting on a thistle by any chance?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I believe I am," said Pooh. "Ow!" He got up, and looked behind him. "Yes, I was. I thought so."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Thank you, Pooh. If you've quite finished with it." He moved across to Pooh's place, and began to eat.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It don't do them any Good, you know, sitting on them," he went on, as he looked up munching. "Takes all the Life out of them. Remember that another time, all of you. A little Consideration, a little Thought for Others, makes all the difference."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: As soon as he had finished his lunch Christopher Robin whispered to Rabbit, and Rabbit said, "Yes, yes, of course," and they walked a little way up the stream together.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I didn't want the others to hear" said Christopher Robin.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It's-I wondered-It's only-Rabbit, I suppose you don't know, What does the North Pole look like."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well," said Rabbit, stroking his whiskers. "Now you're asking me."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I did know once, only I've sort of forgotten," said Christopher Robin carelessly.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It's a funny thing," said Rabbit, "but I've sort of forgotten too, although I did know once."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I suppose it's just a pole stuck in the ground?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Sure to be a pole," said Rabbit, "because of calling a pole, and if it's a pole, well, I should think it would be sticking to the ground, shouldn't you, because there'd be nowhere else to stick it."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "The only thing," said Rabbit, "is, where is it sticking?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "That's what we're looking for," said Christopher Robin.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: They went back to the others. Piglet was lying on his back, sleeping peacefully. Roo was washing his face and paws in the stream, while Kanga explained to everybody proudly that this was the first time he had ever washed his face himself, and Owl was telling Kanga an Interesting Anecdote full of long words like Encyclopedia and Rhododendron to which Kanga wasn't listening.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I don't hold with all this washing," grumbled Eeyore. "This modern Behind-the-ears nonsense. What do you think, Pooh?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: But we shall never know what Pooh thought, for there came a sudden squeak from Roo, a splash, and a loud cry of alarm from Kanga.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Roo's fallen in!" cried Rabbit, and he and Christopher Robin came rushing down to the rescue.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Look at me swimming!" squeaked Roo from the middle of his pool, and was hurried down a waterfall into the next pool.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Are you all right, Roo dear?" called Kanga anxiously.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Yes!" said Roo. "Look at me sw--" and down he went over the next waterfall into another pool.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Everybody was doing something to help. Piglet, wide awake suddenly, was jumping up and down and making "Oo, I say" noises; Owl was explaining that in a case of Sudden and Temporary Immersion the Important Thing was to keep the Head Above Water;

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Kanga was jumping along the bank, saying "Are you sure you're all right, Roo dear?" to which Roo, from whatever pool he was in at the moment, was answering

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Look at me swimming!" Eeyore had turned round and hung his tail over the first pool into which Roo fell, and with his back to the accident was grumbling quietly to himself, and saying, "All this washing; but catch on to my tail, little Roo, and you'll be all right"; and, Christopher Robin and Rabbit came hurrying past Eeyore, and were calling out to the others in front of them.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "All right, Roo, I'm coming," called Christopher Robin.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Get something across the stream lower down, some of you fellows," called Rabbit.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: But Pooh was getting something. Two pools below Roo he was standing with a long pole in his paws, and Kanga came up and took one end of it, and between them they held it across the lower part of the pool; and Roo still bubbling proudly, "Look at me swimming," drifted up against it, and climbed out.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Did you see me swimming?" squeaked Roo excitedly, while Kanga scolded him and rubbed him down.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Pooh, did you see me swimming? That's called swimming, what I was doing. Rabbit, did you see what I was doing? Swimming. Hallo, Piglet! I say, Piglet! What do you think I was doing! Swimming! Christopher Robin, did you see me--"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: But Christopher Robin wasn't listening. He was looking at Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Pooh," he said, "where did you find that pole?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh looked at the pole in both his hands.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I just found it," he said. "I thought it ought to be useful. I just picked it up."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Pooh," said Christopher Robin solemnly, "the Expedition is over. You have found the North Pole!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Eeyore was sitting with his tail in the water when they all got back to him.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Tell Roo to be quick, somebody," he said. "My tail's getting cold. I don't want to mention it, but I just mention it. I don't want to complain but there it is. My tail's cold."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Eeyore took his tail out of the water, and swished it from side to side.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "As i expected," he said. "Lost all feeling. Numbed it. That's what it's done. Numbed it. Well, as long as nobody minds, I suppose it's all right."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Poor old Eeyore. I'll dry it for you," said Christopher Robin, and he took out his handkerchief and rubbed it up.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Thank you, Christopher Robin. You're the only one who seems to understand about tails. They don't think-that's what's the matter with some of these others. They've no imagination. A tail isn't a tail to them, it's just a Little Bit Extra at the back."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Never mind, Eeyore," said Christopher Robin, rubbing his hardest. "Is that better?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It's feeling more like a tail perhaps. It Belongs again, if you know what I mean."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Hullo, Eeyore," said Pooh, coming up to them with his pole.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Hullo, Pooh. Thank you for asking, but I shall be able to use it again in a day or two."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I wasn't talking about anything," said Pooh, looking puzzled.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "My mistake again. I thought you were saying how sorry you were about my tail, being all numb, and could you do anything to help?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "No," said Pooh. "That wasn't me," he said. He thought for a little and then suggested helpfully, "Perhaps it was somebody else."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Well, thank him for me when you see him."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh looked anxiously at Christopher Robin.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Pooh's found the North Pole," said Christopher Robin. "Isn't that lovely?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Is that what we were looking for?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh!" said Eeyore. "Well, anyhow- it didn't rain," he said.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: They stuck the pole in the ground, and Christopher Robin tied a message on to it.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Then they all went home again. And I think, but I am not quite sure, that Roo had a hot bath and went straight to bed. But Pooh went back to his own house, and feeling very proud of what he had done, had a little something to revive himself.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Piglet Is Entirely Surrounded by Water

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: IT RAINED and it rained and it rained. Piglet told

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: himself that never in all his life, and he was

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: goodness knows how old - three, was it, or four? - never

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: had he seen so much rain. Days and days and days.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "If only," he thought, as he looked out of the

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: window, "I had been in Pooh's house, or Christopher

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Robin's house, or Rabbit's house when it began to

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: rain, then I should have had Company all this time,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: instead of being here all alone, with nothing to do

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: except wonder when it will stop." And he imagined

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: himself with Pooh, saying, "Did you ever see such

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: rain, Pooh?" and Pooh saying, "Isn't it awful,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Piglet?" and Piglet saying, "I wonder how it is over

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Christopher Robin's way" and Pooh saying, "I

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: should think poor old Rabbit is about flooded out by

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: this time." It would have been jolly to talk like this,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and really, it wasn't much good having anything

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: exciting like floods, if you couldn't share them with

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: For it was rather exciting. The little dry ditches in

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: which Piglet had nosed about so often had become

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: streams, the little streams across which he had

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: splashed were rivers, and the river, between whose

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: steep banks they had played so happily, had sprawled

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: out of its own bed and was taking up so much room e

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: everywhere, that Piglet was beginning to wonder

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: whether it would be coming into his bed soon.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It's a little Anxious," he said to himself, "to be a

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Very Small Animal Entirely Surrounded by Water.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Christopher Robin and Pooh could escape by

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Climbing Trees, and Kanga could escape by Jumping, and

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Rabbit could escape by Burrowing, and Owl could

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: escape by Flying, and Eeyore could escape by - by

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Making a Loud Noise Until Rescued, and here am I,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: surrounded by water and I can't do anything."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: It went on raining, and every day the water got a

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: little higher, until now it was nearly up to Piglet's

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: window .. . and still he hadn't done anything.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: hasn't much Brain, but he never comes to any harm.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He does silly things and they turn out right. There's

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Owl. Owl hasn't exactly got Brain, but he Knows

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Things. He would know the Right Thing to Do when I

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Surrounded by Water. There's Rabbit. He hasn't

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Learnt in Books, but he can always Think of a Clever

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Plan. There's Kanga. She isn't Clever, Kanga isn't,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: but she would be so anxious about Roo that she

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: would do a Good Thing to Do without thinking

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: about it. And then there's Eeyore. And Eeyore is so

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: miserable anyhow that he wouldn't mind about

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: this. But I wonder what Christopher Robin would

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Then suddenly he remembered a story which

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Christopher Robin had told him about a man on a

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: desert island who had written something in a bottle

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and thrown it in the sea; and Piglet thought that if

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: he wrote something in a bottle and threw it in the

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: water, perhaps somebody would come and rescue

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He left the window and began to search his house,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: all of it that wasn't under water, and at last he found

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: a pencil and a small piece of dry paper, and a bottle

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: with a cork to it. And he wrote on one side of the

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Then he put the paper in the bottle, and he corked

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: the bottle up as tightly as he could, and he leant out

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: of his window as far as he could lean without falling

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: in, and he threw the bottle as far as he could throw -

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: splash! - and in a little while it bobbed up again on

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: the water; and he watched it floating slowly away in

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: the distance, until his eyes ached with looking, and

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: sometimes he thought it was the bottle, and

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: sometimes he thought it was just a ripple on the water

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: which he was following, and then suddenly he knew

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: that he would never see it again and that he had done

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: all that he could do to save himself.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "So now," he thought, "somebody else will have

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: to do something, and I hope they will do it soon,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: because if they don't I shall have to swim, which I

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: can't, so I hope they do it soon." And then he gave a

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: very long sigh and said, "I wish Pooh were here. It's

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: so much more friendly with two."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: When the rain began Pooh was asleep. It rained,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and it rained, and it rained, and he slept

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and he slept and he slept. He had had a tiring day. You remember

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: How he discovered the North Pole; well, he was so

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: proud of this that he asked Christopher Robin if there

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: were any other Poles such as a Bear of Little Brain

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "There's a  South Pole," said Christopher Robin,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "and I expect there's an East Pole and a West Pole,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: though people don't like talking about them."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Pooh was very excited when he heard this, and

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: suggested that they should have an Exposition to

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: discover the East Pole, but Christopher Robin had

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: thought of something else to do with Kanga; so Pooh

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: went out to discover the East Pole by himself.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Whether he discovered it or not, I forget; but he was

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: so tired when he got home that, in the very middle of

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: his supper, after he had been eating for little more

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: than half-an-hour, he fell fast asleep in his chair, and

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Then suddenly he was dreaming. He was at the

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: East Pole, and it was a very cold pole with the coldest

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: sort of snow and ice all over it. He had found a

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: beehive to sleep in, but there wasn't room for his legs, so

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: he had left them outside. And Wild Woozles, such as

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: inhabit the East Pole, came and nibbled all the fur off

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: his legs to make nests for their Young. And the more

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: they nibbled, the colder his legs got, until suddenly

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: he woke up with an Ow! - and there he was, sitting in

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: his chair with his feet in the water, and water all

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He splashed to his door and looked out....

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "This is Serious," said Pooh. "I must have an

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So he took his largest pot of honey and escaped

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: with it to a broad branch of his tree, well above

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: the water, and then he climbed down again and escaped

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: with another pot ... and when the whole Escape was

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: dangling his legs, and there, beside him, were ten pots of

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Two days later, there was Pooh, sitting on his

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: branch, dangling his legs, and there, beside him,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Three days later, there was Pooh, sitting on his

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: branch, dangling his legs, and there, beside him,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Four days later, there was Pooh ...

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And it was on the morning of the fourth day that

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Piglet's bottle came floating past him, and with one

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: loud cry of "Honey!" Pooh plunged into the water,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: seized the bottle, and struggled back to his tree

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Bother!" said Pooh, as he he opened it. "All that wet

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: for nothing. What's that bit of paper doing?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He took it out and looked at it.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It's a Missage," he said to himself, "that's what it

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: is. And that letter is a 'P,' and so is that, and so is that,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: and 'P' means 'Pooh,' so it's a very important Missage

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: to me, and I can't read it. I must find Christopher

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Robin or Owl or Piglet, one of those Clever Readers

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: who can read things, and they will tell me what this

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: missage means. Only I can't swim. Bother!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Then he had an idea, and I think that for a Bear of

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Very Little Brain, it was a good idea. He said to

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "If a bottle can float, then a jar can float, and if

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: a jar floats, I can sit on the top of it, if it's a very

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So he took his biggest jar, and corked it up. "All

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: dropped his boat into the water and jumped in

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE

title: WINNIE THE POOH

title: WINNIE THE POOH

title: WINNIE THE POOH

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Christopher Robin lived at the very top of the

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Forest. It rained, and it rained, and it rained, but the

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: water couldn't come up to his house. It was rather

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: all round him, but it rained so hard that he stayed

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: indoors most of the time, and thought about things.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Every morning he went out with his umbrella and put

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: a stick in the place where the water came up to, and

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: every next morning he went out and couldn't see his

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: stick any more, so he put another stick in the place

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: where the water came up to, and then he walked

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: home again, and each morning he had a shorter way

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: to walk than he had had the morning before. On the

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: him, and knew that for the first time in his life he

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: was on a real island. Which was very exciting.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: It was on this morning that Owl came flying over

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: the water to say "How do you do," to his friend

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I say, Owl," said Christopher Robin, "isn't this

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "There's a lot of water about," explained Owl.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I hope he's all right," said Christopher Robin.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I've been wondering about him. I expect Piglet's

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: with him. Do you think they're all right, Owl?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I expect so. You see, at any moment - "

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Do go and see, Owl. Do you see, Owl?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "That's all right," said Owl. "I'll go. Back

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: In a little while he was back again.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Has been there. He's been sitting on a branch of

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: his tree outside his house with nine pots of honey.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Here I am," said a growly voice behind him.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: They rushed into each other's arms.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "How did you get here, Pooh?" asked Christopher

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Robin, when he was ready to talk again.

title: WINNIE THE POOH

text: "On my boat," said Pooh proudly. "I had a Very

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Important Missage sent me in a bottle, and owing to

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: having got some water in my eyes, I couldn't read it,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: so I brought it to you. On my boat."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE

text: "Isn't there anything about Pooh in it?" asked

text: "Oh, are those 'P's' Piglets? I thought they were

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: with you, Pooh. Owl, could you rescue him on your

text: "I don't think so," said Owl, after grave thought.

title: WINNIE THE POOH

text: Rescue is Coming? And Pooh and I will think of a

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Rescue and come as quick as ever we can. Oh, don't

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: talk, Owl, go on quick!" And, still thinking of

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: something to say, Owl flew off.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I ought to say," explained Pooh as they walked

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: down to the shore of the island, "that it isn't just an

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: ordinary sort of boat. Sometimes it's a Boat, and

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: sometimes it's more of an Accident. It all depends."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "On whether I'm on the top of it or underneath

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "There!"" said Pooh, pointing proudly to the

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: It wasn't what Christopher Robin expected, and

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: the more he looked at it, the more he thought what a

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Brave and Clever Bear Pooh was, and the more

title: WINNIE THE POOH

text: Christopher Robin thought this, the more Pooh

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: looked modestly down his nose and tried to pretend

text: "But it's too small for two of us," said Christopher

title: WINNIE THE POOH

text: "That makes it smaLler still. Oh, Pooh Bear, what

title: WINNIE THE POOH

text: And then this Bear, Pooh Bear, Winnie-the-Pooh,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Companion), P.D. (Pole Discoverer), E.C. and T.F. (Eeyore's

title: WINNIE THE POOH

text: Comforter and Tail-finder)-in fact, Pooh himself -

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: staring, wondering if this was really the Bear of Very

text: Little Brain whom he had known and loved so long.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "We might go in your umbrella," said Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "We might go in your umbrella," said Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "We might go in your umbrella," said Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: For suddenly Christopher Robin saw that they

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: might. He opened his umbrella and put it point

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: downwards in the water . It floated but wobbled.

title: WINNIE THE POOH

text: Pooh got in. He was just beginning to say that it was

title: WINNIE THE POOH

text: "I shall call this boat The Brain of Pooh," said

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: in a south-westerly direction, revolving gracefully.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: You can imagine Piglet's joy when at last the ship

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: came in sight of him. In after-years he liked to think

author: A.A. MILNE

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: been in was in the last half-hour of his imprisonment,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: when Owl, who had just flown up, sat on a branch of

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: his tree to comfort him, and told him a very long

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: story about an aunt who had once laid a seagull's egg

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: by mistake, and the story went on and on, rather like

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: window without much hope, went to sleep quietly

title: WINNIE THE POOH

title: WINNIE THE POOH

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: him time to jerk himself back into safety and say,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "How interesting, and did she?" when - well, you

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: can imagine his joy when at last he saw the good ship,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: The Brain of Pooh (Captain, C. Robin; 1st Mate, P.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Bear) coming over the sea to rescue him.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
