text: And that is really the end of the story, and as

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: I am very tired after that last sentence, I think I shall

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Christopher Robin Gives Pooh a Party, and We Say Good-bye

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: ONE DAY when the sun had come back over the Forest, bringing with it the scent of May, and all the streams of the Forest were tinkling happily to find themselves their own pretty shape again, and the little pools lay dreaming of the life they had seen and the big things they had done, and in the warmth and quiet of the Forest the cuckoo was trying over his voice carefully and listening to see if he liked it, and wood-pigeons were complaining gently to themselves in their lazy comfortable way that it was the other fellow's fault, but it didn't matter very much; on such a day as this Christopher Robin whistled in a special way he had, and Owl came flying out of the Hundred Acre Wood to see what was wanted.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Owl," said Christopher Robin, "I am going to give a party."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "And it's to be a special sort of party, because it's because of what Pooh did when he did what he did to save Piglet from the flood."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh, that's what it's for, is it?" said Owl.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Yes, so will you tell Pooh as quickly as you can, and all the others, because it will be tomorrow."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh, it will, will it?" said Owl, still being as helpful as possible.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "So will you go and tell them, Owl?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Owl tried to think of something very wise to say, but couldn't, so he flew off to tell the others. And the first person he told was Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Pooh," he said, "Christopher Robin is giving a party."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh!" said Pooh. And then seeing that Owl expected him to say something else, he said, "Will there be those little cake things with pink sugar icing?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Owl felt that it was rather beneath him to talk about little cake things with pink sugar icing, so he told Pooh exactly what Christopher Robin had said, and flew off to Eeyore.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "A party for Me?" thought Pooh to himself. "How grand!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And he began to wonder if all the other animals would know that it was a special Pooh Party, and if Christopher Robin had told them about The Floating Bear and The Brain of Pooh and all the wonderful ships he had invented and sailed on, and he began to think how awful it would be if everybody had forgotten about it, and nobody quite knew what the party was for; and the more he thought like this, the more the party got muddled in his mind, like a dream when nothing goes right. And the dream began to sing itself over in his head until it became a sort of song. It was an

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He saved his friend from a wetting!

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Well, Pooh was a Bear of Enormous Brain

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And I don't know if he could swim or not,

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So now let's give him three hearty cheers

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: (So now let's give him three hearty whiches?)

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: And hope he'll grow in health and wisdom and riches!

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: (Just tell me, Somebody-WHAT DID HE DO?)

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: While this was going on inside him, Owl was talking to Eeyore.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Eeyore," said Owl, "Christopher Robin is giving a party."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Very interesting," say Eeyore. "I suppose they will be sending me down the odd bits which got trodden on. Kind and Thoughtful. Not at all, don't mention it."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Yes, I heard you. Who dropped it?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "This isn't anything to ear, it's asking you to the party. Tomorrow."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "You mean Piglet. The little fellow with the excited ears. That's Piglet. I'll tell him."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "No, no!" said Owl, getting quite fussy. "It's you!"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Of course I'm sure. Christopher Robin said 'All of them! Tell all of them.'"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Ah!" said Eeyore. "A mistake, no doubt, but still, I shall come. Only don't blame me if it rains."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: But it didn't rain. Christopher Robin had made a long table out of some long pieces of wood, and they all sat around it. Christopher Robin sat at one end, and Pooh sat at the other, and between them on one side were Owl and Eeyore and Piglet, and between them on the other side were Rabbit, and Roo and Kanga. And all Rabbit's friends-and-relations spread themselves about on the grass, and waited hopefully in case anybody spoke to them, or dropped anything, or asked them the time.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: It was the first party to which Roo had ever been, and he was very excited. As soon as ever they had sat down he began to talk.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Roo jumped up and down in his seat for a little while and then began again.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Piglet waved a paw at him, being too busy to say anything.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Eeyore nodded gloomily at him. "It will rain soon, you see if it doesn't," he said.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Roo looked to see if it didn't, and it didn't, so he said "Hallo, Owl!"-and Owl said "Hallo, my little fellow," in a kindly way, and went on telling Christopher Robin about an accident which had nearly happened to a friend of his whom Christopher Robin didn't know, and Kanga said to Roo, "Drink up your milk first, dear, and talk afterwards."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: So Roo, who was drinking his milk, tried to say that he could do both at once...¦ and had to be patted on the back and dried for quite a long time afterwards.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: When they had all nearly eaten enough, Christopher Robin banged on the table with his spoon, and everybody stopped talking and was very silent, except Roo who was just finishing a loud attack of hiccups and trying to look as if it was one of Rabbit's relations.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "This party," said Christopher Robin, "is a party because of what someone did, and we all know who it was, and it's his party, because of what he did, and I've got a present for him and here it is." Then he felt about a little and whispered, "Where is it?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: While he was looking, Eeyore coughed in an impressive way and began to speak.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Friends," he said, "including oddments, it is a great pleasure, or perhaps I had better say it has been a pleasure so far, to see you at my party. What I did was nothing. Any of you-except Rabbit and Owl and Kanga-would have done the same. Oh, and Pooh. My remarks do not, of course, apply to Piglet and Roo, because they are too small. Any of you would have done the same. But it just happened to be Me. It was not, I need hardly say, with an idea of getting what Christopher Robin is looking for now"-and he put his front leg to his mouth and said in a loud whisper, "Try under the table"-"that I did what I did-but because I feel that we should all do what we can do to help. I feel that we should all-

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Was it me?" asked Roo, a little surprised.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "What's Eeyore talking about?" Piglet whispered to Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I don't know," said Pooh rather dolefully.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I thought it was once. But I suppose it isn't."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I'd sooner it was yours than Eeyore's," said Piglet.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "AS-I-WAS-SAYING," said Eeyore loudly and sternly, "as I was saying when I was interrupted by various Loud Sounds, I feel that-"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Here it is!" cried Christopher Robin excitedly. "Pass it down to silly old Pooh. It's for Pooh."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Of course it is. The best bear in all the world."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I might have known," said Eeyore. "After all, one can't complain. I have my friends. Somebody spoke to me only yesterday. And was it last week or the week before that Rabbit bumped into me and said 'Bother!' The Social Round. Always something going on."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Nobody was listening, for they were all saying "Open it Pooh," "What is it, Pooh?" "I know what it is," "No, you don't" and other helpful remarks of this sort. And of course Pooh was opening it as quickly as ever he could, but without cutting the string, because you never know when a bit of string might be Useful. At last it was undone.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: When Pooh saw what it was, he nearly fell down, he was so pleased. It was a Special Pencil Case. There were pencils in it marked "B" for Bear, and pencils marked "HB" for Helping Bear, and pencils marked "BB" for Brave Bear. There was a knife for sharpening the pencils, and india-rubber for rubbing out anything which you had spelt wrong, and a ruler for ruling lines for the words to walk on, and inches marked on the ruler in case you wanted to know how many inches anything was, and Blue Pencils and Red Pencils and Green Pencils for saying special things in blue and red and green. And all these lovely things were in little pockets of their own in a Special Case which shut with a click when you clicked it. And they were all for Pooh.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Oh, Pooh!" said everybody else except Eeyore.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: But Eeyore was saying to himself, "This writing business. Pencils and what-not. Over-rated, if you ask me. Silly stuff. Nothing in it."

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: Later on, when they had all said "Good-bye" and "Thank-you" to Christopher Robin, Pooh and Piglet walked home thoughtfully together in the golden evening, and for a long time they were silent.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "When you wake up in the morning, Pooh," said Piglet at last, "what's the first thing you say to yourself?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "What's for breakfast?" said Pooh. "What do you say, Piglet?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "I say, I wonder what's going to happen exciting today?" said Piglet.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "And what did happen?" asked Christopher Robin.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Could you think and tell me and Pooh sometime?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He gave a deep sigh, picked his bear up by the leg and walked off to the door, trailing Winnie-the-Pooh behind him. At the door he turned and said "Coming to see me have my bath?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "Was Pooh's pencil case any better than mine?"

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: "It was just about the same," I said.

title: WINNIE THE POOH
author: A.A. MILNE
text: He nodded and went out...¦ and in a moment I heard Winnie-the-Pooh-bump, bump, bump-going up the stairs behind him.

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: Once upon a time, a long, long time ago, it was the custom

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: of all the fathers and mothers in China to give their first and

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: honored sons great long names. But second sons were given

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: In a small mountain village there lived a mother who had

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: two little sons. Her second son she called Chang, which

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: meant 'little or nothing.' But her first and honored son,

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: she called Tikki tikki tembo-no sa rembo-chari bari ruchi-

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: pip peri pembo, which meant 'the most wonderful thing

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: Every morning the mother went to wash in a little stream

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: near her home. The two boys always went chattering along

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: with her. On the bank was an old well.

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: 'Don't go near the well,' warned the mother, 'or you

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: They boys did not always mind their mother and one day

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: they were playing beside the well, and on the well when

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: Tikki tikki tembo-no sa rembo-chari bari ruchi-pip peri

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: pembo ran as fast as his little legs could carry him to his

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: 'Most Honorable Mother, Chang has fallen into the well!'

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: 'The water roars, Little Blossom,' I can not hear you,'

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: Then Tikki tikki tembo-no sa rembo-chari bari ruchi-pip

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: peri pembo raised his voice and cried,

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: 'Oh, Most Honorable One, Chang has fallen into the well!'

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: 'That troublesome boy,' answered the mother. 'Run and

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: get the Old Man With The Ladder to fish him out.'

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: Then Tikki tikki tembo-no sa rembo-chari bari ruchi-pip

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: peri pembo ran as fast as his little legs could carry him to

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: the Old Man With The Ladder and said,

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: 'Old Man With The Ladder, Chang has fallen into the

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: well. Will you come and fish him out?'

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: 'So,' said the Old Man With The Ladder, 'Chang has

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: And he ran as fast as his old legs could carry him. Step

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: over step, step over step he went into the well, picked up

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: little Chang, and step over step, step over step brought him

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: He pumped the water out of him and pushed the air

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: into him, and pumped the water out of him and pushed

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: the air into him, and soon Chang was just as good as ever!

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: Now for several months the boys did not go near the

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: well. But after the Festival of the Eighth Moon they ran to

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: the well to eat their rice cakes.

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: They ate near the well, they played around the well,

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: they walked on the well and Tikki tikki temb-no sa rembo-

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: chari bari ruchi-pip peri pembo fell into the well!

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: Chang ran as fast as his little legs could carry him to his

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: 'Oh, Most Honorable Mother, Tikki tikki temb-no sa

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: rembo-chari bari ruchi-pip peri pembo has fallen into the

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: 'The water roars, Little One,' I cannot hear you,'

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: So little Chang took a deep breath.

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: 'Oh, Mother, Most Honorable,' he panted, 'Tikki tikki

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: temb-no sa rembo-chari bari ruchi-pip peri pembo has

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: 'Tiresome Child, what are you trying to say?' said his

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: 'Unfortunate Son, surely the evil spirits have bewitched

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: your tongue. Speak your brother's name with reverence.'

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: Poor little Chang was all out of breath

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: from saying that great long name, and he

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: didn't think he could say it one more

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: time. But then he thought of his brother

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: Chang bowed his little head clear to the sand, took a

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: rembo-chari bari-ruchi-pip-peri pembo is at the bottom

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: 'Oh, not my first and honored son, heir of all I possess!

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: But there was no answer. Puzzled he waited. Then with

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: his very last bit of breath he shouted,

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: 'Old Man With The Ladder, Tikki tikki temb-no sa

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: rembo-chari bari ruchi-pip peri pembo is at the bottom of

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: 'Miserable child, you disturb my dream. I had floated

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: into a purple mist and found my youth again. There were

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: glittering gateways and jeweled blossoms. If I close my eyes

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: Poor little Chang was frightened. How could he say that

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: 'Please, Old Man With The Ladder, please help my

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: brother out of the cold well.'

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: 'So,' said the Old Man With The Ladder, 'your mother's

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: Precious Pearl' has fallen into the well!'

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: The Old Man With The Ladder hurried as fast as his old

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: legs could carry him. Step over step, step over step he went

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: into the well, and step over step, step over step out of the

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: well with the little boy in his arms. Then he pumped the

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: water out of him and pushed the air into him, and pumped

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: the water out of him and pushed the air into him.

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: But little Tikki tikki temb-no sa rembo-chari bari ruchi-

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: pip peri pembo had been in the water so long, all because

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: of his great long name, that the moon rose many times

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: before he was quite the same again.

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: And from the day to this the Chinese have always

title: TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO
author: ARLENE MOSEL
text: thought it wise to give all their children little, short names

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: There once was a boy named Nikolai who sometimes felt

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: uncertain about the right way to act. 'I want to be a good person,' he told his

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: friends. 'But I don't always know the best way to do that.'

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Nikolai's friends understood and they wanted to help him.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: If only I could find the answers to my three questions,' Nikolai continued,

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: 'Then I would always know what to do.'

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: When is the best time to do things?

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Who is the most important one?

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: What is the right thing to do?

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: to do things, one must plan in

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: when to do things if you watch

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: was just dozing off, rolled over

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: You need a pack to keep watch

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: and help you decide when to do

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: coconut is about to fall on your

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Nikolai thought for a moment. Then he

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: asked his second question. 'Who is the

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Nikolai thought some more. Then he asked the

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: third question. 'What is the right thing to do?'

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: 'Having fun all the time,' laughed Gogol.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Then the boy thought for a long while. He loved his friends.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: He knew they were all trying their best to help him answer his

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: questions. But their answers didn't seem quite rights.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Then, an idea came to him. I know! He thought. I will ask

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Leo, the turtle. He has lived a very long time. Surely he will know

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: the answers I am looking for.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Nikolai hiked up high into the mountain where the old turtle lived all alone.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: When Nikolai arrived, he found Leo digging a garden. The turtle was old and the digging was hard for him. 'I have three questions and I came to ask for your help,' Nikolai said.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: 'When is the best time to do things? Who is the most important one? What is the right thing to do?'

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Leo listened carefully, but he only smiled.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Then he went on with his digging.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: 'You must be tired,' Nikolai said at last. 'Let me help you.' The turtle gave him his shovel and thanked him.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: And because it was easier for a young boy to dig than it was for and old

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Turtle, Nikolai kept on digging until the rows were finished.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: But just as they finished, the wind blew wildly

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: and rain burst from the darkened clouds.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: As they moved towards the cottage for shelter,

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Nikolai suddenly heard a cry for help.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Running down the path he found a panda whose leg had

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: been injured by a falling tree.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Carefully Nikolai carried her into Leo's house and made a

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: splint for her leg with a stick of bamboo.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: The storm raged on banging at the doors and windows.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: 'Where am I,' she said, 'and where is my child?'

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: The boy ran out of the cottage and down the path. The roar of the

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: storm was deafening. Pushing around by the howling wind and drenching rain he ran farther into the forest. There he found the panda's child cold

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: The little panda was wet and scared, but alive. Nikolai carried her inside

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: and made her warm and dry. Then he laid her in her mothers' arms.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Leo smiled when he saw what the boy had done.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: The next morning, the sun was warm, birds

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: sang, and all was well with the world, The

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: panda's leg was healing nicely, and she

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: thanked Nikolai for saving her baby

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: At that moment, Sonya, Gogol and Pushkin

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: arrived to make sure everyone was alright.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Nikolai felt great peace within himself. He had wonderful

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: friends. And he had saved the panda and her child. But he

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: also felt disappointed. He still had not found the answers

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: to his three questions. So he asked Leo one more time.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: The old turtle looked at the boy,

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: 'But your questions have been answered,' he said.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: 'Yesterday if you had not stayed to help me dig my garden you wouldn't have heard the panda's cries for help in the storm. Therefore, the most important time was the time you spend digging the garden. The most important one at that moment was me, and the most important thing to do was to help me with my garden.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Later when you found the injured panda, the most important time was

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: the time you spent mending her leg and saving her child. The most important ones were the panda and her baby. The most important thing

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: to do was to take care of them and make them safe.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Remember then that there is only one important time and that time is now. The most important on is always the one you are with. At the most important

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: thing to do is for the one who is standing at your side. For these, my dear

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: boy, are the answers to what is most important in this world.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Many years ago, I found the three questions mentioned in a book by Thich Nhat Hanh, A Vietnamese Zen Master. When I first read the story, it was if a golden bell in me had struck reminding me that I already knew this tale by heart. Some books are like that and it has happened for me very often with the writer Leo Tolstoy.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: The original short story is not about a boy with animal friends, but a Czar who is looking for answers to three questions. His adventure was of a different kind. Rather than saving a panda and her child, he unwittingly rescues someone who is trying to harm him. By saving his enemy, he creates a profound connection with another human being. I encourage those readers interesting in sophisticated layers of intrigue to out Leo Tolstoy's original story of the same name.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: I wanted to tell this story to a young audience,

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: So its form here is somewhat different than Tolstoy's. I hope he would be honored by this telling. I hope it would make him smile.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: The animal characters borrow their names from many places. Pushkin and Gogol are the names of the famous Russian writers. Sonya was the name of Leo Tolstoy's wife. Nikolai was the name of Leo Tolstoy's brother, and also my son who modeled for the character. Pushkin was modeled for by my dog, Raymond. My daughter Adelaine is the baby panda. And the character Leo is, of course, Tolstoy.

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: Count Leo Tolstoy (1828-1920) Was one of Russia's greatest novelists and

title: THE THREE QUESTIONS
author: JOHN J. MUTH
text: one of its most influential moral philosophers and social reformers. He is renowned as the author of War and Peace (1865-1869) and Anna Karenina (1875-1877) and also is an outstanding thinker of the 19th century. His short story, 'The Three Questions,' on which this book is based, was published in 1903.]]

text: And a little white whale on the go.

title: BABY BELUGA
author: RAFFI
text: You're just a little white whale on the go.

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: it's a sleepover at her house.

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: What should you do when you get to her door?

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Put on a disguise and say,

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: If you like cats, meow. If

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: you like dogs, bark. If you

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: When she opens the door, shout:

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Hug your mom and dad goodbye and say,

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: 'Don't be sad, I'll be home soon.'

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Go to the park to feed the ducks

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Go to the park to swing

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Go to the park to slide

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Go to the park to take photos

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: As the babysitter, you need to let her choose.

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: What to do at the park:

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Slide down the bumpy slide and the

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: twirly slide. If she's feeling brave,

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: try the tallest slide of all.

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: the swing, but not too high.

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Remind her to pump her legs.

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: her how to help the shy

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Don't forget: good babysitters always say,

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: 'Five more minutes!' before it's... 'Time to go!'

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Back at home, plan some more fun.

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: How to play with a grandma:

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Grab two microphones and sing a duet.

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: (You might want to try 'You Are My

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Line up all her shoes to play

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: If your grandma likes fancy things, decorate her with ribbons,

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: bows, and stickers. Shout 'Ta-dah' when you hand her a mirror.

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Soon it's time for dinner. Your grandma may be a

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: yummy cook, but share your ticks to make everything

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Add sprinkles to anything. (Well almost anything.)

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Arrange the food to make silly faces.

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Shut your eyes as you take ach bite and say, 'Mmmmm...'

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: When it starts to get dark,

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Read some books. Turn the pages slowly so she can find

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Ask your grandma for stories about when your mom was little:

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: 'What was Mom's favorite thing to do at the park?'

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: 'Was her grandma as fun as you?'

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: [[Point to your eye, to your heart, and to her.]]

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Now let your grandma choose where

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Once you're both tucked in, make shadow puppets.

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Have your shadow foxes kiss good night.

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: If she's missing your mom and dad,

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: hear a knock, open the door

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: How to say goodbye to a grandma:

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Say I-LOVE-YOU! without making a sound.

title: HOW TO BABYSIT A GRANDMA
author: JEAN REAGAN
text: Give her a BIG hug and ask,

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He was a good little monkey

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: One day George saw a man.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He had on a large yellow straw hat.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: 'What a nice little monkey,' he thought.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: 'I would like to take him home with me.'

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He put his hat on the ground

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: and, of course, George was curious.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He came down from the tree

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: to look at the large yellow hat.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The hat had been on the man's head.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George thought it would be nice

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: to have it on his own head.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He picked it up and put it on.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The man picked him up quickly

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: and popped him into a bag.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The man with the big yellow hat

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: put George into a little boat,

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: and a sailor rowed them both

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: across the water to a big ship.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George was sad, but he was still

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: On the big ship, things began to happen.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The man took off the bag.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George sat on a little stool and the man said,

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: 'George, I am going to take you to a big Zoo

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: in a big city. You will like it there.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: But it is easy for little monkeys to forget.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: On the deck he found some sea gulls.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He wondered how they could fly.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: as they threw him a lifebelt.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George caught it and held on.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: At last he was safe on board.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: After that George was more careful

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: to be a good monkey, until at last,

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George said good-bye to the kind sailors,

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: and he and the man with the yellow hat

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: walked off the ship on to the store

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: and on into the city to the man's house.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: One, two, three, four, five, six, seven.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The fireman rushed to the telephone.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Then they looked for the signal

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: on the big map that showed

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: where the telephone call had come from.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: They didn't know it was GEORGE.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: They thought it was a real fire.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The firemen jumped on to the fire engines

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The firemen rushed into the house.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: 'Oh, catch him, catch him,' they cried.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He almost did, but he got caught

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: a thin fireman caught one arm

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: and a fat fireman caught the other.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: they said. 'We will have to shut you up

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: where you can't do any more harm.'

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: and shut him in a prison.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He climbed up to the window

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Just then the watchman came in.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He got on the wooden bed to catch George.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: But he was too big and heavy.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George ran out through the open door.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: and out on to the roof. And then

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: he was lucky to be a monkey:

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: out he walked on to the telephone wires.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Quickly and quietly over the guard's head,

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: A little girl bought a balloon

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: the wind whisked them all away

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Up, up he sailed, higher and higher.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The houses looked like toy houses

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: At first the wind blew in great gusts.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: on to the top of a traffic light.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The traffic got all mixed up.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George didn't know what to do,

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: and then he heard someone call,

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He looked down and saw his friend,

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: the man with the big yellow hat!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: and the man with the big yellow hat

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Then he paid the balloon man

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: And then George and the man

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: and at last, away they went

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: Down in the big construction site,

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: The tough trucks work with all their might

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: To build a building, make a road,

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: To get the job done-load by load!

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: The sun has set, the work is done;

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: It's time for trucks to end their fun.

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: So one by one they'll go to bed

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: To yawn and rest their sleepy heads,

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: Then wake up to another day

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: Working hard to help his team,

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: Crane Truck raises one last beam.

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: He swings the beam into the sky.

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: He'll set it down right on its mark,

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: Then off to bed; it's almost dark.

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: He slowly folds his boom back in,

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: And then with one last sleepy grin,

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: He tucks himself in nice and tight (sigh!),

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: Then cuddles up and says goodnight.

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: Cement Mixer sings his whirly song.

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: From the fun that keeps him busy.

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: With one last spin, he pours the load.

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: He's ready now to leave the road.

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: He takes a bath, gets shiny-bright,

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: Pulls up his chute, turns off his light.

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: He cuts his engine, slows his drum,

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: And dreams sweet dreams of twirly fun.

text: And dreams of busy days ahead.

author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: Pulls up his boom, stretches his back.

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE

text: He sets his scoop down on the ground

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: And snuggles up without a sound.

author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE
author: SHERRI DUSKEY RINKER AND TOM LICHTENHELD
text: These big, big trucks, so tough and loud,

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE

text: They work so hard, so rough, and proud.

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE

title: GOODNIGHT, GOODNIGHT, CONSTRUCTION SITE

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: My grandfather was a young man when he left his home in Japan

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: and went to see the world.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: He wore European clothes for the first time and began his journey

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: on a steamship. The Pacific Ocean astonished him.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: For three weeks he did not see land. When land finally appeared

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: He explored North America by train and riverboat, and often walked

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: Deserts with rocks like enormous sculptures amazed him.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: The endless farm field reminded him of the ocean he had crossed.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: Huge cities of factories and tall buildings bewildered and yet excited him

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: He marveled at the towering mountains and rivers as clear as the sky.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: He met many people along the way. He shook hands with black men

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: and white men, with yellow men and red men.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: The more he traveled, the more he longed to see new places, and never

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: Of all the places he visited, he liked California best. He loved the

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: strong sunlight there, the Sierra Mountains, the lonely seacoast.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: After a time, he returned to his village in Japan to marry his childhood

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: sweetheart. Then he brought his bride to the new country.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: They made their home by the San Francisco Bay and had a baby girl.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: As his daughter grew, my grandfather began to think about his own childhood.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: He thought about his old friends.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: He remembered the mountains and rivers of his home. He surrounded

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: himself with songbirds, but he could not forget.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: Finally, when his daughter was nearly grown, he could wait no more.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: He took his family and returned to his homeland.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: Once again he saw the mountains and rivers of his childhood.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: They were just as he had remembered them.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: Once again he exchanged stories and laughed with his old friends.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: But the village was not a place for a daughter from San Francisco.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: So my grandfather bought a house in a large city nearby.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: There, the young woman fell in love, married, and sometime later I was born.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: When I was a small boy, my favorite weekend was a visit to my

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: grandfather's house. He told me many stories about California.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: He raised warblers and silvereyes, but he could not forget the mountains

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: And rivers of California. So he planned a trip.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: But a war began. Bombs fell from the sky and scattered our lives

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: When the war ended, there was nothing left of the city and of the house

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: So they returned to the village where they had been children.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: But my grandfather never kept another songbird.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: The last time I saw him, my grandfather said that he longed to see California

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: One more time. He never did.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: And when I was nearly grown, I left home and went to see California

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: After a time, I came to love the land my grandfather had loved,

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: and I stayed on and on until I had a daughter of my own.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: But I also miss the mountains and rivers of my childhood.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: I miss my old friends. So I return now and then, when I can not still

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: The funny thing is, the moment I am in one country,

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: I am homesick for the other.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: I think I know my grandfather now.

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: his grandfather's life in America and

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: Japan, Allen Say delivers a poignant

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: account of his family's unique cross-

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: veys his own love for his two countries

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: and describes the strong and constant

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: desire to be in both places at once:

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: When in one country, he invariably

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: misses the other. His grandfather, he

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: Journey in Allen Say's Most personal

title: GRANDFATHER'S JOURNEY
author: ALLEN SAY
text: and remarkable picture yet of the
