title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Press here and turn the page.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Great! Now press the yellow dot again.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Perfect. Rub the dot on the left... gently.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Well done! And now the one on the right... gently.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Fabulous! Five quick taps on the yellow...

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: And five taps on the red...

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: And finally five taps on the blue.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Perfect. Try shaking the book... just a little bit.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Not bad. But maybe a little bit harder.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: There. Well done. Now tilt the page to the left... just to see what happens.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: And then to the right... a little more.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Excellent! Shake the book one more time just to get everything back in order.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Hmmmm. Interesting. Try pressing down really hard on all the yellow dots.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: That's funny! Turn the lights back on. Try pressing them all again.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Perfect! (Hold on. Two of those dots seem to have switched places. But which ones?)

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Now press hard on all the dots. Really hard.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Not bad. Shake them up a little.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Pretty, isn't it? Try blowing on them... to get rid of the black.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Oooops. That might have been a little bit too hard.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Stand the book up straight to make those dots drop down again.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: There you go! That's perfect! Now, clap your hands once.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Uh-oh, too loud! Quick, press the white dot.

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Bravo! Want to do it all over again?

title: PRESS HERE
author: HERVE TULLET
text: Back to the beginning. This way...

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Six times Miss Hester's dog Fritz had bitten dear

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: cousin Eunice. So when Miss Hester received an

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: invitation to visit Eunice she was not surprised to

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: read 'P.S., Please leave your dog home.' On the

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: day of her visit Miss Hester asked young Alan Mitz

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: to stay with Fritz and give his afternoon walk.

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: As soon as Miss Hester left, Fritz ran into the parlor.

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: He loved to chew on the chairs and shake the stuff-

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: ing out of the pillows. But Alan was ready. All

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: morning long he kept Fritz from sinking his sharp

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: little teeth into the furniture. Finally the dog gave

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: up and fell asleep, exhausted. Alan took a nap, too,

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: but first he hid his hat under his shirt, hats being on

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: of Fritz's favorite things to chew.

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: An hour later Alan quickly awoke when Fritz gave

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: him a bite on the nose. The bad-mannered dog was

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: ready for his afternoon walk. Alan fastened Fritz's

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: leash and the dog dragged him out of the house.

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Walking along, they discovered a small white bridge

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: at the side of the road. Alan decided to let Fritz lead

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Some distance beyond the bridge Alan stopped to

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: read a sign. It said: ABSOLUTELY, POSITIVELY NO

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: DOGS ALLOWED IN THIS GARDEN. At the bottom it

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: was signed: ABDUL GASAZI, RETIRED MAGICIAN.

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Behind the sign stood a vine-covered wall with an

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: open doorway. Alan took the warning quite seriously.

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: He turned to leave, but as he did, Fritz gave a

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: tremendous tug and snapped right out of his collar.

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: He bolted straight ahead through the open door,

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: 'Fritz, stop, you bad dog!' cried Alan, but the dog

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: simply ignored him. Down shadowed paths and

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: across sunlit lawns they raced, deeper and deeper

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: into the garden. Finally, Alan drew close enough to

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: grab hold of Fritz. But as he reached out he slipped

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: and fell. Fritz barked with laughter as he galloped

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: out of sight. Alan slowly picked himself up. He

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: knew he had to find Fritz before Mr. Gasazi discov-

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: ered him. Bruised and tired, he hurried off in the

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: After a long search Alan was ready to give up. He

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: was afraid he might never find Fritz. But then he

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: came upon fresh dog prints. Slowly he followed

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Fritz's tracks along a path that led into a forest. The

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: dirt path ended and a brick walk began. There were

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: no more tracks to follow, but Alan was certain that

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Alan started running. In front of him he could see a

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: clearing in the forest. As he came dashing out of the

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: woods he stopped as quickly as if he had run up

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: against a wall. For there, in front of him, stood a

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: truly awesome sight. It was the house of Gasazi.

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Alan nervously climbed the great stairs, convinced

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Fritz had come this way and been captured.

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: The boy's heart was pounding when he arrived at

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: the huge door. He took a deep breath and reached

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: for the bell, but before he touched it the door swung

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: open. There, in the shadow of the hallway, stood

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Gasazi the Great. 'Greetings, do come in' was all

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Alan followed Gasazi into a large room. When the

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: magician turned around Alan quickly apologized for

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: letting Fritz into the garden. He politely asked that

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: if Mr. Gasazi had Fritz, would he please give him

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: back? The magician listened carefully and then,

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: smiling, said, 'Certainly you may have your little

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Fritzie. Follow me.' With those words he went to

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: the door and led Alan back outside.

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: They were walking across the lawn when suddenly

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Gasazi stopped by a gathering of ducks. He began to

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: speak in a voice that was more like a growl. 'I

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: detest dogs. They dig up my flowers, they chew on

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: my trees. Do you know what I do to dogs I find in

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: afraid to hear the answer. 'I TURN THEM INTO

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: DUCKS!' bellowed Gasazi. In horror, Alan looked

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: at the birds in front of him. When one duck came

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: forward, Gasazi said, 'There's your Fritz.' Alan

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: begged the magician to change Fritz back. 'Impos-

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: sible,' he answered, 'only time can do that. This

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: spell may last years or perhaps just a day. Now take

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: your dear bird and please don't come again.'

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: When Alan took the bird in his arms it tried to give

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: him a bite. 'Good old boy,' said Alan sadly as he

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: patted the bird on the head. 'You really haven't

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: changed so much.' With tears in his eyes he started

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: for home. Behind him Alan could hear Gasazi

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: laughing. As he approached the stairway, a gust of

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: wind took Alan's hat sailing right off his head. Run-

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: ning along with one arm reaching for the hat, Alan

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: lost his hold on Fritz. The duck flew out ahead and

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: grabbed the hat in midair. But instead of landing he

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: just kept on flying, higher and higher, until he disap-

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Alan just stood and stared at the empty sky. 'Good-

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: bye, old fellow,' he called out sadly, sure that Fritz

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: was gone forever. At least he had something to chew

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: on. Slowly, one step after another, Alan found his

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: way back to the garden gate and over the bridge. It

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: was sunset by the time he reached Miss Hester's.

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Lights were on and he knew she must be home.

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: With a heavy heart he approached the door, wonder-

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: ing how Miss Hester would take the news.

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: When Miss Hester came to the door Alan blurted

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: out his incredible story. He could barely hold back

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: the tears; then, racing out of the kitchen, dog food on

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: his nose, came Fritz. Alan couldn't believe his eyes.

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: 'I'm afraid Mr. Gasazi played a trick on you,' said

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Miss Hester, trying to hide a smile. 'Fritz was in the

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: front yard when I returned. He must have found his

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: own way home while you were with Mr. Gasazi. You

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: see, Alan, no one can really turn dogs into ducks;

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: that old magician just made you think that duck was

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Alan felt very silly. He promised himself he'd never

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: be fooled like that again. He was too old to believe

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: in magic. Miss hester watched from the porch as

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Alan waved goodbye and hurried down the road to

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: go home. Then she called out to Fritz, who was

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: playfully running around the front yard. He came

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: trotting up the front steps with something in his

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: mouth and dropped it at Miss Hester's feet. 'Why

title: THE GARDEN OF ABDUL GASAZI
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: you bad dog,' she said. 'What are you doing with

title: THE NIGHT BEFORE MOTHER'S DAY
author: NATASHA WING
text: when, as quiet as a mouse,

title: THE NIGHT BEFORE MOTHER'S DAY
author: NATASHA WING
text: to get Mom out of the house.

title: THE NIGHT BEFORE MOTHER'S DAY
author: NATASHA WING
text: Her sneakers were set by the doorway with care

author: NATASHA WING
text: in hopes that her running pals soon would be there.

author: NATASHA WING

title: THE NIGHT BEFORE MOTHER'S DAY
author: NATASHA WING
text: and jogged off in a snap.

author: NATASHA WING
text: Away to the kitchen we flew like a flash

author: NATASHA WING
text: as if we were running a one-hundred-yard dash!

title: THE NIGHT BEFORE MOTHER'S DAY
author: NATASHA WING
text: When Mom came home, she saw the mess in the sink.

title: THE NIGHT BEFORE MOTHER'S DAY
author: NATASHA WING
text: The next morning we presented a giant bouquet.

title: THE NIGHT BEFORE MOTHER'S DAY
author: NATASHA WING
text: 'It's for you, Mom!' we cried. 'Happy Mother's Day!'

title: THE NIGHT BEFORE MOTHER'S DAY
author: NATASHA WING
text: She read both of our cards

author: NATASHA WING
text: We took Mom to the kitchen

title: THE NIGHT BEFORE MOTHER'S DAY
author: NATASHA WING
text: where our spa was set up.

title: THE NIGHT BEFORE MOTHER'S DAY
author: NATASHA WING
text: then we dabbed on a mud mask.

title: THE NIGHT BEFORE MOTHER'S DAY
author: NATASHA WING
text: Dad said, 'The chef will be serving

text: We took seats at the table,

author: NATASHA WING
text: When what to our wondering eyes should appear-

author: NATASHA WING
text: but the perfect model for Mother of the Year!

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Little Bo-Peep has lost her sheep,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And can't tell where to find them;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Leave them alone, and they'll come home,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And bring their tails behind them.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And dreamt she heard them bleating;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: But when she awoke, she found it a joke,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: For still they all were fleeting.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Then up she took her little crook,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: She found them indeed, but it made her heart bleed,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: For they'd left all their tails behind 'em!

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: It happened one day, as Bo-peep did stray

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: There she espied their tails, side by side,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: All hung on a tree to dry.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: She heaved a sigh and wiped her eye,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And over the hillocks she raced;

author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And tried what she could, as a shepherdess should,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: That each tail should be properly placed.

text: Little Boy Blue, come, blow your horn!

text: They had not then been drowned.

author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Ye parents who have children dear,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And ye, too, who have none,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE

text: Pray keep them safe at home.

text: Sit by the fire and spin;

text: Take a cup and drink it up,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Had spoiled his nice new rattle.

text: Just then flew by a monstrous crow,

author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: As big as a tar barrel,

author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Which frightened both the heroes so,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Dear, dear! what can the matter be?

author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Two old women got up in an apple-tree;

text: "Lend me thy mare to ride a mile."

author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "Alack! and I must keep the fair!

text: I'll give thee money for thy mare."

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE

text: Little Robin Redbreast sat upon a tree,

text: Down came Pussy-Cat, away Robin ran,

author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Says little Robin Redbreast: "Catch me if you can!"

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Little Robin Redbreast jumped upon a spade,

author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Pussy-Cat jumped after him, and then he was afraid.

author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Little Robin chirped and sang, and what did Pussy say?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Pussy-Cat said: "Mew, mew, mew," and Robin flew away.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: My mother sent me for some barm, some barm;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: For fear the young men should do me some harm.

author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Yet didn't you see, yet didn't you see,

author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And kissed my sister instead of me.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Jack be nimble, Jack be quick,

author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: How many were going to St. Ives?

author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Hush, baby, my dolly, I pray you don't cry,

author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And I'll give you some bread, and some milk by-and-by;

author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT

author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT

text: You find milk, and I'll find flour,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And we'll have a pudding in half an hour.

author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: If wishes were horses, beggars would ride.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "Little girl, little girl, where have you been?"

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "Gathering roses to give to the Queen."

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "Little girl, little girl, what gave she you?"

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "She gave me a diamond as big as my shoe."

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: The King of France went up the hill,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: The King of France came down the hill,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: A peck of pickled peppers Peter Piper picked.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: If Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Where's the peck of pickled peppers Peter Piper picked?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And beat the Knave full sore;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And vowed he'd steal no more.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "Little maid, pretty maid, whither goest thou?"

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "Down in the forest to milk my cow."

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "Shall I go with thee?" "No, not now;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: When I send for thee, then come thou."

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: WHAT ARE LITTLE BOYS MADE OF?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: What are little boys made of, made of?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: What are little boys made of?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And that's what little boys are made of."

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: What are little girls made of, made of?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: What are little girls made of?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "Sugar and spice, and all that's nice;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And that's what little girls are made of."

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: As I was going to sell my eggs

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: I met a man with bandy legs,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: I tripped up his heels, and he fell on his nose.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: When I was a little girl, about seven years old,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: I hadn't got a petticoat, to cover me from the cold.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: So I went into Darlington, that pretty little town,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And there I bought a petticoat, a cloak, and a gown.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: I went into the woods and built me a kirk,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And all the birds of the air, they helped me to work.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: The hawk with his long claws pulled down the stone,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: The dove with her rough bill brought me them home.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: The parrot was the clergyman, the peacock was the clerk,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: The bullfinch played the organ,--we made merry work.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: WHERE ARE YOU GOING, MY PRETTY MAID

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "Where are you going, my pretty maid?"

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "May I go with you, my pretty maid?"

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "What is your father, my pretty maid?"

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "My father's a farmer, sir," she said.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "What is your fortune, my pretty maid?"

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "My face is my fortune, sir," she said.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "Then I can't marry you, my pretty maid."

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: There was an old woman of Gloucester,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Whose parrot two guineas it cost her,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: To the talkative woman of Gloucester.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: The Rule of Three doth puzzle me,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Little King Boggen, he built a fine hall,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Pie-crust and pastry-crust, that was the wall;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: The windows were made of black puddings and white,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And slated with pan-cakes,--you ne'er saw the like!

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Bell horses, bell horses, what time of day?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: One o'clock, two o'clock, three and away.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Taffy was a Welshman, Taffy was a thief,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Taffy came to my house and stole a piece of beef;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: I went to Taffy's house, Taffy was not home;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Taffy came to my house and stole a marrow-bone.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: I went to Taffy's house, Taffy was not in;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Taffy came to my house and stole a silver pin;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: I went to Taffy's house, Taffy was in bed,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: I took up the marrow-bone and flung it at his head.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And what will poor robin do then,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And hide his head under his wing,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: There was an old woman of Harrow,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: To announce the old woman of Harrow.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Young Roger came tapping at Dolly's window,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: He asked for admittance; she answered him "No!"

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "No, no, Roger, no! as you came you may go!"

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: There was a piper had a cow,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And he had naught to give her;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: He pulled out his pipes and played her a tune,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And gave the piper a penny,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And bade him play the other tune,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: A little old man of Derby,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: How do you think he served me?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: He took away my bread and cheese,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And that is how he served me.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And when he meets a pretty girl

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: He takes her by the hand;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: All the way to Bristol, oh!

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: There was an old woman who lived in a shoe.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: She had so many children she didn't know what to do.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: She gave them some broth without any bread.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: She whipped them all soundly and put them to bed.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: I went to the wood and got it;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: I sat me down to look for it

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And brought it home because I couldn't find it.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: There was an old woman in Surrey,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Who was morn, noon, and night in a hurry;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: The worrying old woman of Surrey.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: I have seen you, little mouse,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Through the hole your little eye

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Hoping soon some crumbs to steal,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: To make quite a hearty meal.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: If she's gone, you'll quickly run

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: To the larder for some fun;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: To choose the daintiest that's there,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Spoiling things you do not care.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: There was a little boy and a little girl

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Says the little boy to the little girl,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Says the little girl to the little boy,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Says the little boy to the little girl,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And all the bread and cheese I got

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: I laid up on the shelf.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: I was forced to go to London

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And the lanes were so narrow,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: I was forced to bring my wife home

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And my wife had a fall;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Sing, sing, what shall I sing?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Cat's run away with the pudding-string!

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Do, do, what shall I do?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: The cat has bitten it quite in two.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: How shall we build it up again?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: How shall we build it up again?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Build it up with silver and gold,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Build it up with silver and gold,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Silver and gold will be stole away,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Silver and gold will be stole away,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Build it up with iron and steel,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Build it up with iron and steel,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Iron and steel will bend and bow,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Iron and steel will bend and bow,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Build it up with wood and clay,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Build it up with wood and clay,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Wood and clay will wash away,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Wood and clay will wash away,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Build it up with stone so strong,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "What is the news of the day,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Is gone up to the moon!"

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: As I went through the garden gap,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Who should I meet but Dick Red-cap!

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: A stick in his hand, a stone in his throat,--

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: If you'll tell me this riddle, I'll give you a groat.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: There was a little woman, as I've been told,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Who was not very young, nor yet very old;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Now this little woman her living got

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: By selling codlins, hot, hot, hot!

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Would make a baby cry and laugh.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: There was an old man of Tobago

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Who lived on rice, gruel, and sago,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "To a leg, sir, of mutton, you may go."

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: What a naughty boy was that,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: To try to drown poor pussy-cat.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Who never did him any harm,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: But killed the mice in his father's barn!

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: A farmer went trotting upon his gray mare,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: With his daughter behind him so rosy and fair,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: A raven cried croak! and they all tumbled down,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: The mare broke her knees, and the farmer his crown,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: The mischievous raven flew laughing away,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And vowed he would serve them the same the next day,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Christmas is coming, the geese are getting fat,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Please to put a penny in an old man's hat;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: If you haven't got a penny a ha'penny will do,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: If you haven't got a ha'penny, God bless you.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "Willy boy, Willy boy, where are you going?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: I will go with you, if that I may."

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: "I'm going to the meadow to see them a-mowing,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: I'm going to help them to make the hay."

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: THE DEATH AND BURIAL OF POOR COCK ROBIN

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: All the birds of the air

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: When they heard the bell toll

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: The mouse ran up the clock;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: One a penny, two a penny,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: With silver buckles on his knee:

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: He'll come back and marry me,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Oh, dear, what can the matter be?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Oh, dear, what can the matter be?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Oh, dear, what can the matter be?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Johnny's so long at the fair.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: He promised he'd buy me a bunch of blue ribbons,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: He promised he'd buy me a bunch of blue ribbons,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: He promised he'd buy me a bunch of blue ribbons,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: To tie up my bonny brown hair.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: There dwelt an old woman at Exeter;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: When visitors came it sore vexed her,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: So for fear they should eat,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: She locked up all her meat,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: This stingy old woman of Exeter.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: If you sneeze on Monday, you sneeze for danger;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Sneeze on a Tuesday, kiss a stranger;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Sneeze on a Wednesday, sneeze for a letter;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Sneeze on a Thursday, something better.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Sneeze on a Friday, sneeze for sorrow;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Sneeze on a Saturday, joy to-morrow.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: How do you do, Mistress Pussy?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: I fare as well as you!"

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: WHEN THE SNOW IS ON THE GROUND

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: When the snow is on the ground,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: For the trees have no leaves,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And no berries can be found.

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: The air is cold, the worms are hid;

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: For robin here what can be done?

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: Let's strow around some crumbs of bread,

title: THE REAL MOTHER GOOSE
author: BLANCHE FISHER WRIGHT
text: And then he'll live till snow is gone.
